column10: one of best car sims in all subcats and best in rally lol

[h1] Dirt and tarmac: Rally and Rallycross [/h1]
Note: I played DiRT Rally 2.0 with my wheel, the G923. I don't have experience of playing this game with a controller. 

[h2] Career [/h2]
The career mode in DiRT Rally 2.0 is kind of basic in my opinion. You do rally, you do another rally, you do more rally. The only big difference between the career and¬† custom events are the thing that the career gives you money. I played the career, but I doubt I'll play it ever again. Daily events are just more fun for me. 

[h2] Daily/Weekly/Monthly events [/h2]
These events are fun. Especially the daily events. These events are a stage/rally/multiple rallies with a specific car class/car.
The best thing about this is that it makes you try different cars you might not have tried, if this wouldn't exist. And also, these events give you money. Daily event rewards are okay, but when I completed a monthly event (which was about 3 hours long) I got about 300 000 credits. And my position on the leaderboards wasn't even that good. Now, lenght. Daily events are often 1 stage, weekly events are multiple stages or 1 rally, and monthly events are very big, maybe even having more than 6 rallies. 

[h2] Historic [/h2]
Historic is another career-like thing, but this time, it's from cars from the beginning of rally all the way to today.
It's a pretty nice mode, especially since the older cars are often slower, and the newer cars are faster, so I found it helpful with me learning to control the faster cars. One sad thing though is that it doesn't give you a lot of rewards. 

[h2] Stages and Cars [/h2]
The stages in DiRT Rally 2.0 are good. They don't feel empty, and they look good. The game of course has DLC to get more locations, the ones I like are Sweden and Finland (Since I live in Finland).
The cars look good too, I like the interior view. 
If you are going to buy this game, I recommend you to get the Game Of the Year Edition, and on sale. I got it for about 10 euros I think. 

[h2] Handling [/h2]
DiRT Rally 2.0's handling is what I would expect. It feels good to drive, isn't extremely hard to control and gives a good experience. Some say that the tarmac handling isn't good, but I don't see anything wrong with it.
Force feedback is nice, it's good and feels connected to the game. 

[h2] Sound [/h2]
The sounds in DiRT Rally 2.0 are very good. When in interior view, it actually sounds like you are inside the car. There isn't soundtrack when you are driving, but the menu music is good (in my opinion). 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
DiRT Rally 2.0 is great to look at, feels good to drive and sound good. The only problem is that there isn't enough things to do other than do rallies. I like the daily events, but for now, I will give DiRT Rally 2.0 a [b]9/10[/b]. Now that you hsve read this review, I recommend you to check out other reviews. Thank you.

[i]Dirt Rally 2.0[/i] is by far the best rally game there is, and one of the best racing games ever. Both [i]WRC Generations[/i] and [i]WRC 2023[/i] are mediocre compared this one. And you can get the GOTY edition regularly for 10 ‚Ç¨, so it is also a lot cheaper than the WRC games. You cannot imagine what people in the community would pay for a DLC for this game with 5 new rally locations.

Pros:
* Excellent physics.
* Great selection of tracks and cars.
* Nice car tuning options.
* Great graphics, the tracks look stunning in some of the weather conditions.
* Well optimized, runs fine on older hardware.
* Lot's of dirt and gravel tracks, which I love. There's also tarmac of course.
* Career mode, custom championships, free roam, and everything else you would expect. I like time trial.
* Still active servers and new daily, weekly, monthly online events.
* Support for VR.
* Good support for steering wheels and pedals. One should keep in mind though that you will not be able to hit buttons for handbrake and shifting up/down on the wheel, as you will be turning it back and forth at very high speeds all the time in rally racing, so a separate shifter [i]and[/i] handbrake is almost required. I have both.
* Also plays very well with a controller. I played with XBox controller a lot before I got my wheel. I would strongly suggest not to play such a game with a keyboard though.
* Cheap: often available for 10 ‚Ç¨ during sales/in other shops, including everything (GOTY edition).

Neutral:
* includes RallyCross events. It's well made, and if you are into it, you will like it. I'm not particularly interested, I prefer pure Rally. Therefore I think it's great that they put it into a separate Rally Cross career, so I do not have to do it if I don't want it.
* The career mode is okay, but nothing special. It's all about driving, no story or management stuff. I actually prefer it this way. I don't want to manage mechanics, I want to drive rally.
* I would prefer less cars and more rally locations instead.

Cons:
* No difficulty settings in main campaign (only assist on/off, but nothing affecting AI difficulty), and some pretty harsh difficulty spikes. This is really minor though, since you can create custom championships in which you can configure the AI difficulty from 1 to 100.
* UI could be improved. In general too few explanations and too little documentation, starting at the game settings, over missing information on the weather conditions and length of a daily event you are about to accept, and ending at missing explanations for the car tuning options. Makes it even tougher for beginners. Watch youtube videos on D2R car tuning if you struggle with the RWD cars (which you will).
* Too much RX (rally cross).
* Team upgrades are too expensive, it takes ages to get them all. An option to decrease repair costs would also be nice, as career mode exposes you to quite expensive and very dangerous cars (Group B) very early. In general I would not start the career mode until you have at least 30 hours in the game.

This is the gold standard for rally games, no doubt about it. If you are only slightly interested in Rally and do not own it, get it. [h2]9.5/10[/h2] in total for me. Keep in mind though that this is [b]not[/b] an arcade racing game: you [b]will[/b] have to invest some time to master it. I now have 80 hours in and I know most of the tracks and can drive them more or less consistently in okay times without major crashes in most conditions with no assists using the lower to mid tier cars. I still have some way to go to be able to handle the power of the latest cars though. I can say the game gets better and better the more you play it, it's amazing.

I haven't played for long, but I'm absolutely stunned by how well made this game is. This game is by the same guys that made Colin McRae rally series, especially "2", I loved that game growing up, me and my dad would spend endless hours playing on split screen, and this game is like a grown, more mature version of that game. My favorite thing about this game is how you constantly have to keep the car perfectly balanced, the difference between left foot braking and not doing it is day and night. There are a lot of ways you can improve, but don't need to master everything at once in the beginning to have fun. Every track and event has multiplayer LAP TIMES, it lets you use any ghost of any player to improve step by step. All in all, best racing game ever so far, the only issue I really have is that it requires non stop connection that takes a long time to load every time you switch a menu screen. I've seen a lot of people complain because the game is too hard, it's not, you're not supposed to get 1st place while not using breaks every time you play. It's not a game for people who don't have a basic understanding of how physics work

This game is NOT for the faint-hearted. When you know how to control the vehicle, it is a thrilling simulator that grabs all of your attention so you can win the race. Even at the low speeds with a Lancia Fulvia, it still feels crazy.

The hardcore sim gamer's heaven lies here. When you are doing the rally, going slow on a bend is the least of your concerns. You are worried about rolling the car into a ditch and losing a lot of time, or even being completely out of the race due to terminal damage.

My only problem is with this game is that your career is saved on Electronic Arts' cloud. Meaning you cannot progress offline, you can only do free-play offline.

Still, an awesome sim that deserves a look, and yes, I am aware that the new Electronic Arts World Rally Championship game is out, but last time I checked, I think it was more expensive and had mixed reviews.

Dirt Rally 2.0 has incredibly realistic mechanics, including driving physics that accurately simulate the feel of different surfaces. The game's attention to detail is impressive, capturing the nuances of rally driving. Well, I must say that Dirt Rally 2.0 is quite an experience. The driving mechanics are extremely realistic, particularly the way it simulates the feel of various surfaces. It's a challenging game that puts your skills to the test, similar to real rally racing. However, I wish the tracks were more varied. The Oculus Rift CV1 experience greatly enhances immersion. It almost feels like you're out on the track, which is thrilling and intense. Overall, a solid game for rally enthusiasts, but it could benefit from more depth in terms of gameplay. Overall, I'd say Dirt Rally 2.0 is a game that I, can appreciate. The realism of the driving mechanics and the immersion of the Oculus Rift CV1 experience make it an exciting choice for rally enthusiasts like myself. While there are some areas where it could improve, particularly in track variety, the thrill of the race is definitely there. So yes, I'd say I quite like this game.

I honestly wanted to like this game, I really did. I just am not the right demographic for the game. I know this is supposed to be a realistic racing sim but I found little enjoyment in it. I personally do not recommend it because of the reasons I listed but I know there are people who enjoy this kind of thing.

This is not the first time Fischer has courted controversy over the role of co-drivers. In 2009, after finding himself without a co-driver for the Jyvaskyla Rally in Finland, he kidnapped a homeless man and forcibly strapped him into the passenger seat to ensure that the two-people-in-each-car rule was complied with. The stunt only came to light when onboard footage taken during the race revealed that rather than reading the ‚Äòpace notes‚Äô, the Finnish co-driver was in fact screaming the words ‚ÄòOh shit!‚Äô over and over again, occasionally interspersed with other phrases including, ‚ÄòWatch out for that house‚Äô and ‚ÄòSlow down, you mad bastard‚Äô.

If you want something less Sim, designed for controllers, that will make you feel like your good, but your actually not and is otherwise poorly developed and optimised, then get the new EA WRC 23, dont get Dirt 2.0, its not for you... but if you want a more sim like experience, something which forces you have some skill, is best played with a wheel and not controller, then Dirt 2.0 maybe for you. 

Dirt 2.0 also in some regards is graphically superior to the latest release and is better optimised (though still far from were it should be, still miles above most AAA these days, as the new EA WRC 23 proves once again), so Dirt 2.0 you can crank those settings up much more reliably then the new release were even though for the dated graphics it should run butter smooth with max settings on older harder = it obviously doesnt and dirt 2.0 easily wins in that comparison.

Dirt 2.0 is more likely to be compatible with your sim devices out the box, unlike the new EA WRC 23.

Dirt 2.0 also has VR, which if you have VR you wont want to ever go back to non-VR once you try it, it makes the whole multi display setups redundant for the full sim experience. Meanwhile the new EA WRC 23 has no VR... not surprising when it doesn't run as good as dirt 2.0 and doesnt really look better then Dirt 2.0, so obviously some serious issues under the hood = yea thats not a good combo for VR, so if you want VR and the best sim experience best bet is Dirt 2.0 by a large margin.

Dirt 2.0 is still missing some features other games have that would certainly take it up a grade, but with EA in charge = never happening, its now a console game franchise, so sim gamers and PC users are just an afterthought, so the current top sim games for rally hasnt changed, anyone who says otherwise is obviously just wanting a more easy casual experience, its as simple that. virtually every youtube positive review which says its got better physics etc etc, repeats the same tag line and never goes into the details, never focus on this and shows proper examples, why? its just what they want to believe or what they have been paid and promoted to say...  often the latter, hence the copy/past review dialogue, because they are told to say it and like wise... not say or do other things part of the review which would obviously show they are in denial or just shilling for publisher perks, as after all early access to games for review and preview = $$$.

still worth pointing out though dirt 2.0 physics aint perfect either, its not a perfect game, but its decent and compared to other games certainly in the top 3, something which already suggested EA didnt change with its 23 release, but also EA WRC 23 aint the worst either, but Dirt 2.0 is definitely better for sim and best with a wheel indicating its sim focus, were EA WRC 23 is fine with a controller for obvious reasons, indicating compromises were made in simulation, track/vehicle physics so console players would not rage quit, so its not that hard to choose which game is right for you depending on your play style and setup.

Riding on the redline, you approach a corner at too great a speed. Your co-driver thinks you're a fool, but being pre-programmed he cannot voice his displeasure, nor his fear. You panic brake, but it's too little too late ... the car's tyres cannot cope. The car steps away from you and you scramble for control. You jerk the wheel this way and the other, trying desperately to avoid oversteering in your bid to keep the car on course. Either by virtue of your skills or via the aid of sheer dumb luck, you make it through. Your car continues to careen down the track, right on the edge of control. There it is again ... that feeling ... euphoria! 

If that's what it means to be a "racing sim", well ... I'm all here for it.

[h1]The Dark Souls Of Rallying[/h1]
DiRT Rally 2.0 dares you to carve your way through a selection of iconic rally locations from across the globe, in the most powerful off-road vehicles ever made, knowing that the smallest mistake could end your stage. You will need to rely on your instincts with the most immersive and truly focused off-road experience yet, including a new authentic handling model, tire choice and surface degradation. Power your rally car through real-life off-road environments in New Zealand, Argentina, Spain, Poland, Australia and the USA, with only your co-driver and instincts to guide you.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üíæGraphics[/td]
        [td]I really enjoy the graphics in this game. Many locations are really well detailed and look really unique from each other. The skybox depending on the time of day and weather can look incredible. Also the vehicles models are well designed with a good damage model. The UI is clean and simple, and fits the game aesthetic perfectly. I have to say though that most rally stages are not demanding or technical. The only locations I had struggles on are Australia, and Argentina.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéÆGameplay[/td]
        [td]The gameplay is actually really good. The overall driving is really challenging and fun, especially if you are a rally fan. There is no rewind in this game so if you crash, you can just go back to a certain part and redo your mistake. I like this because this promotes serious and focused driving that punishes mistakes. The older titles (besides DiRT Rally) had a rewind mechanic and it never really felt challenging in my opinion. You have a good list of vehicles to choose from and they all feel pretty unique from each other. You also have Rallycross which I enjoyed a ton especially with friends. Rallycross also has a good list of cars and a decent amount of tracks. The rally stages though are pretty disappointing (for the base game). The base game just lacks a good amount of replayability because the stages are not super long, and you don‚Äôt get many locations. I highly recommend getting the Game of the Year edition. I‚Äôll even say that it‚Äôs essential to have! If you get the GOTY edition, then yes will you have double the amount of rally stages and even more Rallycross stages. You even get more rally and Rallycross vehicles to choose from. The overall physics is pretty well done. The gravel is really well done and feels slippery, especially on wet stages (which are the best for gravel). Speaking of wet, the tarmac stages in the wet are horrible. I do not like the tarmac physics that much here. It feels floaty and just doesn‚Äôt feel natural. I'm also not a fan of the tire and damage mechanics. It all feels forgiving and at worse, and afterthought. For example the suspension never really gets worn out on long rallies. You still have to be somewhat cautious on damage, but it's not as brutal as some say it is. Also the AI can be really inconsistent. Like the AI feels the same in terms of speed even in different weather conditions. I feel like they should be a bit slow at night or in the wet. While you are struggling to see in the rain at night, the AI just rockets away! It‚Äôs freaking annoying and makes it feel unbalanced at times. I usually have to play on a lower difficulty just to somewhat balance them. It could be a skill issue, but I see many people complain about it so it may just be a design flaw.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üìúStory[/td]
        [td]The campaign mode is pointless. I don‚Äôt really see a reason to play it. It‚Äôs linier, boring, and doesn‚Äôt really offer anything fun. You can‚Äôt even make your own team car livery. It feels like an afterthought. Also you don‚Äôt really get any unlockable to use. The progression is also non-existent. At least allow me to truly make my own team, and not just hire mechanics. You do have daily and weekly challenges which can be fun, but why is this tied to the campaign? Like I have to buy certain cars from the campaign just to use in the challenges against other players. Why not just make it its own game mode separate from the campaign. It doesn‚Äôt really make much sense.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üïõPlaytime[/td]
        [td]The playtime is pretty solid here. You can add a good amount of time if you enjoy a good challenging rally game or if you are a fan of rallycross. You have a decent amount of stages (even a good majority don‚Äôt feel long). It can get kinda repetitive since the campaign mode doesn‚Äôt really add anything of value.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéßSound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is so incredible! Every car feels impactful and truly immersive. The loud pops and bangs and hitting the rev limiter sound awesome! The voice notes sound really good so I have no problems with that. The overall sound in this game is a banger and definitely one of the best sounding racing games out there.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùóBugs‚ùó[/td]
        [td]I haven't really encountered any bugs. The game felt pretty well polished. I‚Äôm sure the game had issues early on, but now it feels really good.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîÖPerformance[/td]
        [td]I had a pretty good performance. I tweaked some graphics settings so I am playing on mostly high settings and now getting a solid 60 fps. Also I get no stutters or crashes so that‚Äôs a big plus![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚úîÔ∏èPro‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Beautiful stages
[*]Controller friendly
[*]Many vehicle classes
[*]Superb sound design
[*]Great Rallycross selection
[*]Semi Realistic handling model
[*]Testing area (great for practice)
[*]Daily, weekly, and monthly Challenges
[*]Tons of awesome rally cars (both modern and retro)
[*]Able to create online lobbies for rally stages/rallycross
[*]Upgrade your team (hire new people and improve their stats)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùåCon‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Forgiving damage model
[*]Tarmac physics are really bad
[*]Base game lacks many locations
[*]Wet tarmac feels horrible and unrealistic
[*]AI feel really inconsistent and unbalanced at times
[*]Career mode feels pretty bland and not rewarding
[*]AI don‚Äôt seem to be affected by weather conditions
[*]Can‚Äôt create your own team car livery (Dirt 4 had this option)
[*]Most Stages (although beautiful) are not technical or demanding 
[*]Buying GOTY Edition gives you tons of money and cars in the beginning of career (ruins the progression)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üèÜRating[/td]
        [td]6/10
Buy the Game of the Year edition instead. This game is worth $40 for all of the extra content.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîóConclusion[/td]
        [td]DiRT Rally 2.0 is a fantastic rally game for the most part. Yes, it has some serious problems like the lack of a good campaign mode, and the AI being OP in certain situations. Besides its flaws, the game plays really well with controller, you have a good list of stages and vehicles, and provides an immersive rally experience. Pick this game up if you want to dive into the Rally world and explore what makes rallying so awesome and terrifying. If you are a Rally fan than definitely grab this title as well![/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Steer clear of DR2, EAWRC and whatever else EA releases while their have the WRC license as hostage; it [i]will[/i] sooner than later become de-listed abandonware much like its predecessors given the parasitic advertisement of their newest disposable release under this page. If and how Steam even allows this is beyond me.

The game is also unplayable in VR unlike advertised, even on a 2023 high-end build - between the constant unexplained framerate dips which cause reprojection issues and stuttering on every model of headset, ruining all but the most casual of runs. These issues will never be fixed because Codemasters/EA never cared, and none of the community's attempts to fix these issues really work (custom dlls, shaders, placebo cfgs, gpu driver settings and more). The physics are also a simplified, unnatural mess. Sounds and visual immersion are great until you're finally caught up with the headache from looking at watery, jittery reprojected frames due to the constant frame dips. If you're very desperate for a rally experience, just pirate it since online isn't likely to work in a year's time anyway.

So far seems pleasing to drive. Pace notes TBC; wish there was a "note stack" option as in Richard Burns Rally; to limit the number of pacenotes called ahead, but otherwise seems good so far.
Edit: After some more rallying I found the pacenotes quality and consistency to be lacking which means you can't trust the pacenotes and push, sort of defeating the purpose of having pacenotes. Look into 'Dirty Pacenotes' plugin where you can use custom pacenotes. I even wrote a little python pacenote editor app seach for 'pacenote map video editor' although the time required to update all pacenotes turned me off. For what is meant to be a focussed rallying game there really needs to be some control over pacenotes: Min & Max call time/distance configuration, max stackup, detail level etc.

To put it short; if you want any aspects below, you won't regret buying DR2.0 even one bit.

- realistic driving physics and car dynamics (one of the best games for this)
- an immersive rally experience
- be your biggest enemy
- become a better driver irl (my own experience)

The one more or less big downside is:

- the lack of diversity -> more locations and cars would have been strongly appreciated.

The 1 ABSOLUTELY annoying thing:

- Dirt Rally's registering of gear shifting. You have to shift like in super slow motion. Otherwise the game won't register it and you land in neutral. So you basically have to shift twice into the very gear to get one gear up or down. And that happens to many times to count... So beware of that.

Solution: That problem can be corrected by editing the deadzone of the clutch in the settings.

Anyway, I can recommend the game to everyone who is curious to try it.

Understeer or Oversteer, which is better?

Understeer is when you are making a turn but you end up sliding forward right into a tree, killing you.
Oversteer is when you take a turn too hard and end up spinning your car into a tree, killing you.
Oversteer is preferred because you at least don't see the tree that kills you.

This game is hard. But **** is it rewarding. You'll think, "Impossible," "No Way," but there is a way and it is possible. It's called Practice. Not Allen Iverson practice, but real practice. I've played every rally game made from Dirt 1 to WRC 5 to Generations back full circle to Codemasters and EA with WRC 2024 or whatever it's called. But this is the one I come back to. This is the one that makes my fingers numb cause I'm gripping the wheel so tight, cutting off circulation. This is the ONE.

DiRT Rally 2.0 in short is a rally racing game in the category of [i]sim-cade[/i]. Don't get me wrong, it is a fun and challenging game compare to older and arcady versions like DiRT 3 or Colin Mcrae: DiRT.

First up, i'll state the good things [b]I like[/b] about DiRT Rally 2.0:
It feels very satisfying to play, and a lot of times, having those close-calls during flat-out moment is thrilling, intense and dangerous, just like any rally person would tell you including Colin Mcrae himself. And surprisingly, it runs 30 fps on my crappy 2013 laptop equipped with A10-5740M despite this game release in 2019 which is a plus in my book. And content wise, this game has plenty of them, and even more surprisingly is that all of the rally/rally-cross maps are [b]based on real-world location[/b], something even extremely rare for me to witness it from a rally game genre. (No, don't tell me other games can do that with "mods", cuz I'm talking about the base game content, not community creation content.) For car varieties, it is plenty enough to play in my opinion.

[b]Edit: After more playing and some research from other player feedbacks, yes, indeed I am aware that the game physics are not entirely simulated, the center of gravity/pivot point of vehicle is and always located at the center of the vehicle no matter how you drive. And secondly, about the FWD vs AWD vs RWD statement I've made, I accept that it maybe as close as it gets to "real-life" handling which I cannot judge since I only drove on asphalt roads irl in Perodua Axia 2014 and Toyota Vios 2013 E spec vehicles. Buuuut, I will keep my ONLY statement about tarmac, ESPECIALLY ON SPAIN rally tracks. Other than that, I believe it's mostly nearly feels like how rally/driving should be[/b]


And for the Rally-Cross, as any player who played any driving games back in 2000 era, you would know how horrible it will be in this game as well. Because, this game made them more idiotic, literally any AI driver that is one position in front of you will try to "block" you aggressively by pushing you towards walls when driving side by side, while any one position behind you will try to "cut" you off by pushing you off the road like no big deal. (which makes me mad and fu*king rammed that as*hole sideways off the road) Therefore in return only encourages reckless/aggressive driving to obtain a better position.

And last problem I had is the one and only, "CONNECTING TO RACENET". Like christ, I understand they don't want anyone to tempered the game files to accelerate or cheat the progression system, but at least make Quick Play, Free Play, Historic Championship, and Colin Mcrae career accessible in offline... (Unfortunately, that will not be the case, Greedy EA and lazy Codemaster got their a*s tied up by arbitrary corporate agreement conditions)

[i]Edit: The reason I put this game in a "sim-cade" category is how the game physics interacts with the in-game environment and player input doesn't translate "realistic". Any veteran or real drivers playing this game will point out how "understeer" is practically minimal to non-existential at all. The vehicle you're driving will turn no matter how aggressive you slam your wheel to full left/right, it will still turns fairly easily which defeats the purpose of consciously minding vehicle weight distribution at all.[/i]


Overall, DiRT Rally 2.0 is a fun game. It's definitely not flawless, but it serves well in terms of content variety and car handling in most cases.
If you like Rally and Rally-cross.  Play this game.

Update Jan 2024: I'll give it a positive because of all the hours of rallying I was able to get out of it. The game continues to have a lot of immersion breaking visual and audio bugs since launch. Has gotten better over time, you can now actually see the track, but it's still jarring when navigators' voice changes between sections. I'll leave the rest as was 3 months since launch.
-----
Even after preordering, I think my patience with the game has reached the end. I so much wanted to give this game a positive review, but I just can't. We are now over 3 Months after launch, they have reluctantly patched the FFB after fan backlash, but most of the issues with the game from launch are still there. 

The main one from the start was, Racenet, no matter how you try to spin this, always online career makes this game abandonware wainting to happen. This wouldn't be such a problem if it wouldn't make the overall experience so laggy/slow. Instead of instant menu navigation quite often you get this wierd lag while racenet synchronizes.

Even 3 Month in, I still can't see where I'm supposed to drive on some track/conditions combinations. The lighting and reflections have been an issue since day 1, yet, other than very minor changes some tracks continue to be to dark or too bright. The developer that thought that dynamic brightness is a good idea needs to be fired. Also the guy who thought making grass reflective. On each track there is at least 1 situation where the track is pure white(flood lights in hairpins on wet track) and you can't tell where to drive. This used to be a big issue at launch where 80%+ of the tracks were either night or rain. Now it still is a lot but was dialed down after backlash.

3 Months in, Pace-notes continue to be inconsistent with different recorded sessions, pacing, and some calls are wrong. Even with pace notes pushed to as early as possible there still are some corners where you are in them when the pace note gets said.

THE killer features of the game, tire type and track degradation are a gimmick right now. Use soft tire everywhere! Having played this game for some time so far, I can't say I've ever had "challenge" from track degradation. So let's call these features what they are, gimmicks.

The challenge is also a joke. Once you upgrade your team, penalties and repair times are basically non-existent. I honestly wanted to restart my profile a couple of times and just not upgrade the team, it's that bad. Without the upgrades a penalty kills your championship, with them you go from minutes worth of penalties to mere seconds. Same goes for car repairs. Without updates you can't completely fix your car after an event, with, fixed car after each service session.

So overall, the game is very inconsistent, some issues are very jarring instantly pulling you out of immersion. 

On the plus side, Physics are a big improvement. Cars drive better, handling is better, but the overall presentation makes these good parts moot. The game overall is an improvement over Dirt Rally, but if just feels so unfinished, unpolished and inconsistent most of the times.

DR 2.0 does one thing really, really well: Simulating the thrill of going really really fast and speeding and sliding right past lethal obstacles while looking good, non stop.

In that sense it captures the thrill of rallying very well, and cutting corners while going as fast as you can is an awesome feeling.

The sense of speed is good, the car damage is pretty nice, nighttime looks decently dark.

It does fall short in a few places though.

The tracks can be a bit dull and especially samey within the same region, with not a ton of variety, and an almost randomly generated feeling at times.

The car liveries are quite meh too, with videogamey 'Dirt 2.0' logo's on your car, and the interface kinda sucks. There are way too many steps between finishing a custom event and selecting a new course and car and unless you set up a playlist in advance you will have to go to the main menu every single time to set up a new quick event.

And finally, I miss my Toyota's.

Still a decent game and there's absolutely fun to be had.

While this still is a good rally game, as opposed to most other entries in the Dirt franchise, that is all there is in this one.
And you might be saying 'boy, it sure looks like it has the word Rally in the title' and you'd be right. Problem is, the franchise name implies that there is at least some progression to run through, some sort of team managing, sponsors or even an arcade section to pit you against AI-based times and ultimately other players. And there really isn't much of that here. At all. You're pretty much given all the content at the start and are expected to run through it at whatever pace you like.

Enjoy more good rally simulations across various environments if you'd like. But expect nothing beyond that.

Great gaming experience, but first, you need to make sure you have a solid will to challenge yourself. I still remember the first event when I started with R2 group in the Historic menu as my first choice, since the cars is easy to drive. Of course, as a rookie, the difficulty is set to 1 (very easy) with all the assists on. The Argentina stages shocked me with narrow roads and lots of open and hairpin corners. I restarted numerous times because of punctured tire, falling off, steaming radiator. I managed to survive the first 2 stages and thought I'm getting the trick. Then the 3rd stage came, a pitch black night with heavy rain, and my screen turned black in less than 20 seconds after I hit the rocks of the 2nd corner due to slippery road. Yes, the headlights are gone. I drove carefully and slowly after being taught in a tough way in that stage. I learned making to the finish line in one piece is far more important than being recklessly fast, and you will be fast by driving smoothly. The further I explored the game, the more challenges I faced. Like the Dark Souls, the joy of mastering the game is quite thrilling compared to arcade style racing games. Wish you find more joyful feelings in the suffering challenges.

I should start by saying I bought DR2 plus all(?) the DLCs as a package while they were heavily discounted. I would NOT recommend buying the DLCs for full price which would be well over ¬£100 including the base game...
With that out of the way I am going to give DR2 (with all DLCs included) a resounding thumbs up. The physics are good but not sadistically hard to get to grips with, even if using the keyboard as a controller. Having said that, some of the RWD cars in particular, do need some setup adjustments to make them less oversteery if not using a wheel and pedals.
The pace notes sound a lot more professional than those in DR1 to my ears, and the stages and rallycross all feel a bit more polished and realistic. Online daily/weekly/monthly challenges are all still very active with several hundred times being clocked in each event every day.
9.5/10

I absolutely LOVE this game! The graphics and audio sounds and queues are so good. Even with only 32 hours of gameplay at the time of this post, i can confidently say that this is one of my favorite games to play when my friends aren't online. The only complaint that I have about this game is that you really need to invest in a bunch of the DLC's in order to make money. Without them it becomes a challenge, especially when first starting out. although, the DLC's go unlock some fun events and tracks, they take a while, but even if you play for an hour a day, you will be able to finish 2-3 monthly challenges if you have the tracks and vehicles purchased. The races can get a little long, for example, when you first start out, if you pick a 10 mile track, you may take upwards of 15 minutes to complete it. This is not the case most of the time however. You will usually get a track anywhere from 2-7 miles, with a 8,9, or 10 sprinkled in between every 1-2 events inside the monthly or weekly challenges. I can 100% recommend this game to a friend. The experience is so amazing with a racing wheel, and if you were to buy this game, I would recommend thinking about investing into one for this game. It doesn't have to be expensive though, and can be a very basic entry wheel. Some thing like the Thrustmaster T248, T300, or even the Logitech G920 or G923, which as of now, are all under $400.00. I would confidently say this product is worth the price, and even better than WRC 10.

Is it Pretty? yes.
Is it fun? Yes.
Is it Realistic? Kind of.
Is it a true simulation? About as close as Forza Motorsport or Gran Turismo is to being a road racing sim. It's a simcade.

Is it the most authentic feel for rally racing one can get in a game? No. RSF's Richard Burns Rally is far superior in that aspect. 

If you are looking for a rally game with a feel good factor, that looks beautiful, and will give you that fast paced on the edge of your seat action you want... this game is outstanding. Very unforgiving game. The learning curve is brutal. The controller support is great, I have a logitech g29 wheel and I still find myself playing with the xbox series controller from time to time.
Learning to drive FWD historic is hard.
Learning to drive RWD historic after FWD is extremely hard.
Learning to drive AWD after learning to drive RWD looks easy by comparison.
The game is at times infuriating, with a minor inconvenience (crashing into an unfortunately placed tree or ROCK, or launching myself off a cliff) right before the finish is a common occurrence.
The challenge is what makes it worth it to me. It is fun seeing my consistency improve. 
The RWD cars are extremely tough to control, it is even tougher to drive them fast, it is very rewarding to be able to control them. At first those cars seem undriveable, but with practice, it is very much becoming something very enjoying.
I want to finish this game or at least get bored before seeing what the new WRC game is like.

1) Payed DLCs in the form of unlocking the rest of the cars and stages. The advertised price of the product is highly misleading. You will need to spend multiple times over the advertised price in order to enjoy the full content of the game. One's expectation is to be asked to pay once and receive the full pack for a transparent and reasonable price. Additional/follow-up payments to unlock the full game content is a consumer-unfriendly practice in my opinion.

2) No Cross-play, so I cant play with my friends with an Xbox or PS4. I cannot even see the ghosts of people I play multiplayer with on PC. They could have spent a bit more effort on the multiplayer part in my opinion.

On the positive side, there is VR support, unlike the F1 games up until now.

Dirt Rally 2.0 has a difficult learning curve but if you're willing to get past that then you may also find this to be the most rewarding racing game.  It's honestly the most fun game I own and I would highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in rally and/or racing.  My only advice is to look up ways on YouTube on how to adjust the input settings on your force-feedback wheel (if you have one) to optimize its performance with the game.

One of the best rally sims out there with the only real competitors being its predecessor Dirt Rally 1 and RBR. The graphics are fantastic, cars are plenty, and driving sensation both on a wheel and controller are immaculate. FFB is not as good as you'd expect, customization of those settings are minimal but enough to give a decent driving feel and experience. The stages are well crafted and fun to drive on, however aren't as diverse as the real life roster. The reuse of stages from the old Dirt Rally is also a bummer.

The only couple gripes is that the pace notes aren't always accurate and aren't as early as some might prefer to be, the earliest setting can still be late at times. and the DLC structure of the game is baffling.

braaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaap

Played on Steam Deck at 50FPS and fairly high graphics settings. Very occasional framerate dips on specific parts of specific stages (one or two tracks in Argentina and certains spots at night in New England).

I uninstalled this game a month ago because I felt that I was putting time into it that could have been better spent on my very extensive backlog of other games. With 240 hours played, I clearly like it! I wisely chose the GOTY edition at ‚Ç¨10 on sale, which has enough variety of tracks and cars for 1000 hours. I would have "upgraded" to the new WRC game, which is essentially a sequel to DR2.0, but the Steam Deck is not powerful enough to reach the level of graphics that I would find adequate for that game.

As many other reviewers have noted, the handling is not perfect, and is the least good aspect of the game, especially on tarmac tracks. Specifically, the back end of the car may unexpectedly slide out for no apparent reason, or more than it should, due to the position of the "centre of turning" of the car, which can ruin a stage and thus an entire rally. If you only play this game and not any other racing games, it is possible to adapt to this phenomenon to a large extent, and the quality of the rest of the game compensates for this issue.

You really need to set up each car correctly for each track - using setups by such people as Rally Technical on YT, if you are not already proficient in technical minutiae. I wish that there were an easier way to configure the cars, because there are literally thousands of different "optimal" setups, taking account of the 82 cars, 169 stages and multiple weather situations in the game. If you could import setups from a file or online, that would greatly improve the game for most players. You CAN play with default setups, but you will be at a great disadvantage 99% of the time.

I don't have much more to say - this is a great game if you want a fun but very challenging rally experience, with lots of variety and few negative aspects, and at fantastic value when on sale. That being said, if I were rich and had a powerful enough PC, I would get the new game instead - it is recognised by more or less all reviewers to be an improved version of this game in every way.

I got Dirt 2 back when it was free on the PS4 with PS+. I have to say the good memories weren't just because it was free; I recently bought it when it was on sale and I have to say it is probably one of the better games I have bought over the past 3 years. I have put many hours in other games such as Warthunder, Warzone 2 etc, however I only felt myself playing them for the sake of it, with nothing better to do and just to progress skins and research trees. However this game provides something more when you make a turn cleanly or finish first. Big crashes also make for a good look at the replay and often look lethal in first person. It always makes me appreciate how skilled rally drivers are in the real world and how it is a more genuine and skilled sport than F1 and NASCAR as it doesn't require driving in a circle on asphalt on a sunny day, however driving on shit 'roads' with it pissing it down. In the end this game always drew me back during lockdown and really helped me gain an understanding of what cars are really capable of with the right driver.

First af all purchase the full version published in 2020 (40 ‚Ç¨) and not the 2019 version at 20 ‚Ç¨ where you need to purchase each car  and circuit  one by one, you will save money!
My specs (Asus rog G20 purchased in 2017): i7-6700 CPU 3,40 Htz, 16GB Ram, GTX 1060 6GB Ram, Win 10 home 64 bits, 256 GB SSD + 1TB mechanical HDD.
Triple screen configuration : 59 Htz 27  inches (2560 x 1440 f per screen = WQHD)
Resolution used for Dirt Rally 1.0 : 7680 x 1440
Resolution used for Dirt Rally 2.0 : 4580 x 1080

Yes I recommend this game if you have the adequate PC. Mine is fine at a resolution of 2560 * 1440 (medium details everywhere excepted textures and shadow in ultra) or in 4580 * 1080 (medium details nearly everywhere excepted textures and shadow in high).
I cannot play in native resolution (7680*1440 with Nvidia surround), details are low or ultra low, a nightmare.
Bug inside : some stages are really dark (New zealand)  and nearly unplayable. this isssue doees not exist in the  original Dirt Rally 1.0. Even if you replace in the My documents/Dirt Rally 2.0 settings "HDR  1,0" by "HDR 0,1", there is no change.

Game is fun, there is no need to play the "campaign mode", just play  solo in "time attack" mode, so that you run against your own  ghost. Do not play on line since you play alone and you just compare your time with those online. It is better to see the ghost of yourself and to beat yourself (there is a leaderboard showing your time agaiinst the best players in time attack mode).  There is also  a custom rally mode where you select the stages of the rallys you like including the weather.
I am an occasionnal driver so this game is perfect but a patch should correct the dimness in game. I was not able to  find a solution  on the net to fix this.
I also use the  sweet FX add-on from RaceDepartment so that image on screen is nicer (at a FFPS cost).

Dirt Rally 1.0 (created in 2015) is still useful since you  have a lot of details at native resolutiion with high settings everywhere, impossible to have this with Dirt Rally 2.0 (created in 2019).
i thought Dirt rally 2.0 could better run on my specs. If your PC is old, stick to the original game.
However at my resolution (4580 x 1080) DIrt Rally 2.0 (with vsync on)  provides a better sensation of speed than Dirt  Rally 1.0 using the same resolution (wiith vsync off). This is strange.

I am using a Logitech G920, it is recognized at once but be prepared to struggle to find appropriate settings on the net. It is less complicated on Dirt Rally 1.0 even if the default settings have to be changed too.

Dirt Rally provides more cars and circuits but their darkness is a real problem.
You do not have those issues in DIrt Rally 1.0.

I still enjoy dirt rally 2.0 but keep this in mind before any purchase.

Edit : Dimness issue solved thx to  Dirt Rally 2 VR eye accomodation fix v2.0.

Here below you will find what I did to improve the game after hours of researches for game improvement. I share with you the results, they are worth it!

Instructions to improve the game :
1. Apply shaders (reshade exe file) / use same exe file to uninstall shaders
2. Copy GTV-DR-2.ini into main Dirt 2.0 folder
3. Copy lut.png into Steam\steamapps\common\dirt 2.0\reshade-shaders\textures 
4. Change reshade.ini (in main Dirt 2.0 folder)
in [INPUT]
Replace "KeyOverlay=32.0.0.0" with "KeyOverlay=113,0,1,0"
5. In game, type SHIFT F2 to get rid of top horizontal bar
6. If too much blue in reshade :  Open reshade, go to "Lift Gamma Gain" and play with "RGB Gamma"
7. In main Dirt 2.0 folder, rename dxgi.dll into d3d11.dll (this is a big file, 3.385 kb to be kept)
8. To reduce dimmness, disable HDR, in My documents\dirt rally 2.0\hardware_settings_confg.xml --> edit it and replace <hdr level="1.0" />
with <hdr level="0.1" />. However this does not seem to work a lot...
9. Steering wheel saturation change: in  Steam\steamapps\common\dirt 2.0\input\libraries, replace lib_direct_input.xml with a file of the same name (the one with saturation deadzone = 1.0)
10. New audio : install audio directory (does not originally exist) in Steam\steamapps\common\dirt 2.0\game\audio.
11. HDR fix from Dirt VR (no more  excessive dimness/darkness in game) : copy dr2vrfix.cfg into Steam\steamapps\common\dirt 2.0 (do not copy d3d11.dll)
12. Add more FFB in Wheel (by default ffb_force = 1.0)  : in Steam\steamapps\common\dirt 2.0\game\input\devices\devices\defines.xml, change the line 
 <device id="{C262046D-0000-0000-0000-504944564944}" name="lg_g920" priority="100" type="wheel" />
into  :
<device id="{C262046D-0000-0000-0000-504944564944}" name="lg_g920" priority="100" type="wheel" ffb_friction="5.0" ffb_force="1.2" />

Files used:
* HDR Fix : Dirt Rally 2 VR eye accomodation fix v2.0 from http://www.kegetys.fi/dirt-rally-2-vr-eye-accomodation-fix-v2-0/
* Graphism update : Reshade setup 5.9.2 from https://reshade.me/
* Audio update (new sound effect enable more sounds all games from codemasters) : DiRT Rally 2 0 Colin McRae FLAT OUT from Racedepartment : https://www.racedepartment.com/downloads/new-sound-effect-enable-more-sounds.36087/
* Wheel update : dirt 2.0 lib direct input from Racedepartment : 
https://www.racedepartment.com/downloads/contoller-fix-add-saturation-as-missing.26692/
* Simhub 9.1.12 (to use tablet as 4th screen): 
https://www.simhubdash.com/download-2/
* Simhub SS Overlay M for Dirt Rally 0.2 transformed into a dashboard : 
https://www.racedepartment.com/downloads/ss-overlay-m1-for-dirt-rally.30824/

This game is awesome. It runs excellently, cars feel amazing and weighty and responsive (well, some feel responsive lol), audio is immersive, tracks are unique, and environments are beautiful. Works great on a controller without any settings adjustments. This game is hard as hell though. I saw someone say its 'the dark souls of racing games' which, yeah, that feels about right. I suck after about 6 hours of play time, but still win enough (in career mode) that I still get money and don't feel depressed about losing too often. There is lots of room to grow and gain mastery and I think i will get a lot of playtime out of this game. Its really just... thrilling. Going so fast and knowing the tiniest mistake will absolutely wreck you is a great (and terrible) feeling.

Great physics but broken AI and difficulty is unnecessarily high. The difficulty  setting which is unavailable for the career mode is all over the place. A difficulty of 40 and a difficulty of 1 doesn't seem to be any different. The progress bar is unhelpful as it actually makes you think you're doing great through the stages but then you'll fall back in positions when you finish the stage. And judging by the "class leader" AI also seems to pull off some impossible speeds. It seems scripted to me as i can see the class leader always getting speed and loosing speed at the same parts of a stage. 

The historic rally championships shouldn't have been locked to a podium finish in order to be able to move on the the next car category since each of these cars will become progressively more difficult to drive. The career mode gets repetitive and it lacks structure, also needs more rally locations. Buying more locations will also not expand your career mode!

It's a bit of a fake echo chamber. If this game had released exactly like this in 2022/2023 it would be a completely different story. It's perfectly playable on a controller and it runs well. I guess you could get something out of it. So its not a total loss. A great handling model alone doesn't make for a great game.

DiRT Rally 2.0 dares you to fail stages hundreds of times in a row due to the physics engine being ported directly from GRID (2008), in cars that feel much closer to go karts on stilts than the real thing, knowing that the smallest bug will end your stage at any second.



This game has SEVERE physics bugs - the weight & inertia of vehicles is calculated for the total of the vehicle ONLY, and as such there is no inertia to the vehicle corners, only the centre of gravity.
This makes all the cars EXTREMELY skittish, EXTREMELY unpredictable and EXTREMELY prone to flying into the sky after driving somewhat near a pebble.

This is an arcade racer with artificial difficulty from physics bugs, NOT a sim.

If not for the atrocious implementation of the co-driver's pace notes the game would be great. However, this is a rally game and co-driver's notes are crucial. For that reason alone I have to be harsh.
One can never have enough confidence to fully rely on the co-driver pace notes to drive fast - they are just too inconsistent. Sometimes the calls are way too early, and other times too late (either there is not enough time to brake, or he calls  mid-corner). Seriously? IRL if co-drivers were so bad half of the WRC drivers would be dead. BTW, it's not Phil Mills fault - it's the way Codies integrated that into the game.
When the pace notes are right DR 2.0 is a pleasure to drive - it gives you a taste of what could have been. When they are wrong however you are either in the trees or off the cliff - it's so frustrating. I don't have time to memorize every stage - and in rally that's not the point!

The game is often on sale and I still recommend to get it then, but don't ever pay full price. DR 2.0 is past development time so it won't ever get fixed. Such a shame, because driving feels superb

I am pretty disappointed, to be honest. DIRT 2.0 has great rep and quite a bit of it is justified - lots of locations, lots of cars, historical campaign, Colin McRae campaign and modern cars campaign, along with with a My Team career where you build up your own team, including your staff, etc. It sounds great and it looks really good too in most places.

However, the game also has a bunch of some pretty questionable UI/QoL issues, such as inability to fix car damage in garage, etc. Furthermore, I also had an issue with it repeatedly disconnecting my Xbox controller, despite it being supposedly natively supported, as well as what I assume was a memory leak that made the performance of the game tank after every couple stages, requiring a restart (or sometimes multiple) to get the game to perform properly again.

At a deep discount, it may be worth it, because when it works, it's definitely one of the (if not the) best rally games in recent years, but the constant controller issues and the necessity to restart the game several times throughout a rally event are just too annoying for me personally to keep playing.

This game, is absolutely amazing. From the fast Group B cars, all the way down to FWD mini coops. Throughout playing this game, you may be frustrated, you may wanna...kill yourself. But you must push through. This is the Dark Souls of racing games, but the reward you feel is unmatched. You begin to fall in-love with your co-driver, as he speaks your course with subtle and direct tongue. And don't even get me started on the Subaru Impreza. God...the things I'd do for an Impreza. I would beat four newborn babies, and slaughter a family of seven, just so I could drive a decked out rally Subaru Impreza 2001. I would suck so much dick, just to be flying down a road at 120mph, while blaring "Don't let me down" by ELO. The absolute down bad, atrocious, downright disrespectful things I would do to drive an Impreza. Anyway, this game is good, very good, a lil too good. It drives you into this loop of insanity. One minute your pumping your fist in the air, full of excitement, and release of stress. The next minute, you're newborn child is hucked 20ft outside of your window, and the police are on they're way. You didn't mean to do it. your car just spun out 30 times, and you almost beat your course PR. None the less, this game will make you fall in love with the sport of Rally Racing. So...should you buy this game? Yes, yes you should, and you should experience all of the fun and hatred that comes with it. 
-Will

So... I've only played DiRT Rally 2.0 in VR, and I had the chance of trying it out in SteamVR and native OculusVR support.

I own an Oculus Rift, and a VIVE Cosmos headset.

I mean, I really love it... Super fun and intense for me. I don't recommend playing with a VR headset whose resolution is too small or pixelated for your eyes, but here's my take on it at least:

I personally believe the Oculus Rift ran far better with the game in terms of performance as long its done in Oculus's own runtime. If through SteamVR, regardless if it was the VIVE or the Oculus headset, the game is really laggy in some areas, leaving me to turn all graphics down to bare minimum so its fluent enough. Didn't matter the internal resolution of the game, it just lags ALOT.

It became unplayable to a point where even the tracking system seemed to fail and became absolutely jittered.

My system may run a RTX 2060 Super / AMD Ryzen 5600X setup, but that shouldn't be the case. The game itself could've been more optimized if Codemasters still worked on it.

Now that they got a new WRC title to care for, I sincerely hope they will improve things once VR's been implemented.

Dirt Rally 2.0 is a game that truly lives up to its name, providing players with an adrenaline-fueled, white-knuckle experience that is as exhilarating as it is infuriating. Developed by Codemasters, this rally racing game takes difficulty to a whole new level, leaving players grappling with frustration as they navigate treacherous tracks filled with unexpected obstacles.

One of Dirt Rally 2.0's standout features is its realistic physics engine, which accurately simulates the dynamics of rally racing. The feeling of sliding through gravel, the responsiveness of the steering, and the impact of each jump are meticulously crafted to offer a genuine rally experience. However, this attention to realism comes at a cost‚Äînamely, a steep learning curve that can leave even seasoned racing game veterans struggling to keep their cars on the track.

The tracks themselves are beautifully designed, winding through diverse landscapes ranging from dense forests to mountainous terrains. However, the picturesque scenery can quickly become an adversary, as tightly packed trees and unforgiving terrain turn what should be a scenic drive into a chaotic ballet of rolling vehicles. It's not uncommon for players to find themselves airborne one moment and careening into a tree the next.

The difficulty of Dirt Rally 2.0 lies not only in the precision required to navigate the tracks but also in the unpredictable nature of the obstacles. The game seems to revel in catching players off guard, with sudden turns, hidden jumps, and deviously placed trees conspiring to send your car spinning out of control. The frustration peaks when, after a particularly challenging section, a simple mistake sends your vehicle tumbling like a pinball, leading to a series of rolls that would make a gymnast jealous.

While some may appreciate the high stakes and the thrill of overcoming seemingly insurmountable challenges, others may find the difficulty level excessive and discouraging. The lack of a gradual difficulty curve may alienate casual players, leaving them feeling more like crash test dummies than rally champions.

In conclusion, Dirt Rally 2.0 is a rally game that lives up to its promise of delivering an intense and challenging experience. The realistic physics, stunning tracks, and heart-pounding moments make it a unique entry in the racing game genre. However, its unrelenting difficulty and penchant for turning a relaxing drive into a chaotic mess may not be for everyone. If you're up for the challenge and have a high tolerance for frustration, Dirt Rally 2.0 might just be the adrenaline fix you're looking for. Just be prepared for a fair share of rolling on the ground and colliding with trees along the way.

The best rally game I've played as of yet, even better that it has stellar VR support. DiRT 2 is beyond rewarding to become proficient at, but brutally punishing upon mistakes. Each corner is a decision; you can either take it slow, hold back, and get around smoothly with little risk. Or, you can send it hot and pray your threadbare tires find traction before your beautiful car goes flying into something hard. Sometimes you'll take a turn too fast and not die; you slide around a bit, but you end up back on track with a minor scrape to the paint. Sometimes you pop 3/4 tires in one crash and have to limp the last mile to the finish. As a gambling enjoyer, this appeals immensely to me, and you'll probably love it too.

I have mixed feelings.

I wouldn't call it a simulator, not in the physics sense. It's a simcade with heavy immersion (would call it "immersive sim"). 
The content and graphics are there but the physics hinders it.

With the starter FWD cars I had no problem but once I got to the RWD and AWD cars. It slaped me. The cars really wanted me to slide into the magnetic clutches of the ditches and valleys a#s first. It just feels really off on gravel and asphalt.

+The co-driver loves to read very late on some stages (like you would need to slow down 50m before the hairpin and he calls it at 20m)

But those moments when everything just connect and you forget the problems and just RATATATATATT VVROOOOOOMMMMMM. Feels great.
+1 point for the singleplayer content.

If you want simulation DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!!!  The physics are rubbish.  No matter what, the car is programmed to flick the rear end out about 1/2 to 2/3 around a corner.  Try doing a circular drift on a free-roam course and you will see what I mean.  I happens on rally stages too.  It is very noticeably artificial.  It ruins what could otherwise be a satisfying corner and game..  It's not my skill or hardware, I run Fanatec DD gear and real life experience.  DO NOT BUY unless you're just after an arcade-like experience.... which you CANNOT DO without being online.

Feels like a great Rally racing game, but I'm not sure if its better than the older DiRT Rally 1 by Codemasters. If you got DR1, maybe hold off cause this seems like its just a more optimized DR1. Unless if you LOVE these games, then pick it up.

Championships have several Events, and the Events have, so far, 4(maybe up to 6 stages/races)

Co-Driver calls: Good and customizable so they could give callouts earlier or later (Again, I havent played DR1 and I dont know if DR1 had it or not.)
Starting an event, they give a layout of the track, the length, the elevation change, the weather, and the terrain so you can plan your tuning setup later.

Graphics: There's several options and it runs very well on High settings on my GTX 1060 6gb, and i7 cpu. I had 60 fps with 1 instance of it dipping to 45 fps over these 8 first hours. I've done maybe 16ish stages/races so far. 
You can change Vsync, multisampling AA, turn on TAA separately,
The minor tweaks you can make involve changing: the mirror fidelity, crowd density, tree LoD, ground cover, skidmarks, weather effects, motion blur, god rays, abberation, bloom, lens flares, light streaks, and lens dust.
Shader, and Texture Detail reflections, shadows are all 


When you start your 1st event, the initial event at least gives you 2 repair stops... which are free until you start experiencing heavy damages I assume.
There's a penalty, which I havent triggered yet once your free repairs goes over 30 minutes of pre-race prep time. This should motivate you to Take it slow and steady as you race to avoid crashing too much. 
Once you begin the 1st event/ race, it prompts you 1 last time to Tune your car and change your tires.
The setups aren't casual or barebones. I'd say they're just right as they give you the gear ratios, suspensions, dampers, and


I haven't played the MP nor do I want to. I may later... but I just enjoyed Colin McRae Rally 04 when I was 9 so maybe I'll attempt it when I get a wheel and pedal system. I've only played the 1st championship with 6ish events on an xbox one controller and I enjoyed it in third person. Later this week, I'll attempt the game on a Logitech G920 Wheel from 1st person mode and see how it handles. I'm excited since its my first wheel. 

EDIT: I may update this review after I've gotten my G920 wheel.

Update April 8th, 2020.

After returning to this game last month, and having all the DLC's now that they reduced the prices to a reasonable level, I can say, that me and this game have a love hate relationship. There are few games that give me the same level of intensity and fun in one go, but simultaneously, there are few games that can make me rage in an instant due to poor game design or bugs.

There are bugs where you will hit invisible objects, sometimes right in the middle of the road/track, sometimes they will just slow you for a moment and then you are good, other times they will fling you off the track or just blow out a tire for no apparent reason. When this happens during a good run, it's easily one of the most infuriating, and disheartening things I've ever dealt with across all of gaming. (This honestly would be easily made less frustrating if the game had rewinds, but the community for this game is apparently too weak minded to not use something they don't like so they basically demand they be left out of the game entirely) 

There is also a problem with loud, inaccurate and just flat out wrong stage notes (Think "4 left, 3 right" etc) Some will be 300% louder than all the other callouts, which is distracting to say the least. Then others you will get "3 left into 3 right" and the 3 right will be twice as sharp so you fall off a cliff. And then there are some that are just wrong, like one stage on Germany where the callout is "4 left, tightens to 3" and it's actually a 3 left, opens to 4. All of this gets better as you learn stages, but there are a lot of stages and once you quit playing for awhile, you're screwed.

I had one genius tell me I should learn every course so I'm thinking 3 turns ahead lol. This line of thinking in my opinion is absurd, because there are 100s if not 1000s of turns in this game, and not many people are going to /only/ play dirt rally and nothing else.

Then comes the problem of multiplayer, you cannot set up a custom championship with rallies and stages you want to run, and run it with a friend, quit mid way and come back later. You have to do the entire championship in one setting. You simply don't have the option to continue the campaign with the people you were playing with, though you can continue it alone, which is the dumbest thing I've ever seen in a game in the 2010s/2020s when it comes to multiplayer.

Me and my friend have been forced to run a few rallies then quit, set up a new championship when we come back run a few quit, and then when we finally finish the championship we wanted, add up the points between each set for us and the AI to determine where we finish. Its silly that we can't just continue the rally.

I don't want to use racenet to set up random rally championships, so don't bother suggesting that. I want to pick each stage individually because I have tested the ones we run to make sure there are little to no loud call outs.

Single player Career mode, I give a 1/10 because I can't play it offline.

Single player content usable offline including custom championships I rate 8/10, the game is a lot of fun when it works properly, and its challenging. Would be a 10/10 for me without all the bugs and poor stage notes.

Multiplayer - custom championships and such - 2/10 because you can't continue once you leave the lobby.

Multiplayer through race net - NA/10 because I don't give a damn about that.

Overall, 5/10. The physics are for the most part great, its a hell of a lot of fun to play when the game is working properly. Unfortunately multiplayer options are trash, and there is a ton of annoying bugs and other issues that ruin an otherwise great game. 

Their focus on E-sports ruined this games multiplayer IMO.

A great rally game that gets a negative review due to its negatives outweighing the positives, the biggest issue being always online:

Negatives:
-Always online requirement for a SINGLEPLAYER GAME meaning:
	-If you have no broadband or an unreliable ISP you can't play at all, mid stage connection loss? Tough luck, back to the main menu.
	-Steams weekly scheduled maintenance means you can't play at all during that time.
	-The game has to wait for validation with the server increasing load times when starting a rally, entering the race events menu, accessing cars in garage menus, uploading a leaderboard time at the end of every single stage etc.
	-Career progress can be reset to 0 for some people when servers detect discrepancy between local and cloud data.
-After losing connection to servers trying to reconnect can crash the game lol. (Only happened once).
-DLC model which recycles content from Dirt rally 1. Thankfully all DLC can be obtained at once with the GOTY edition.
	-DLC locks out legendary rally vehicles like the Lancia 037, Subaru Imprezza (2001), Subaru Imprezza S4, Peugeot 206. There's a lot of rallycross car DLC too.
-Lack of modding in a SINGLEPLAYER GAME compared to Dirt rally 1 due to DLC files being unalterable (cant mod DLC car liveries and even base game cars have only 1 or no liveries that can be replaced. Why not let us add to the list of liveries like the game Art of rally.)
-4WD up to 2000cc class consists of entirely DLC cars.
-Few real liveries for vehicles

Postives:
-Very good physics on all surfaces, not perfect but very good.
-Stages are based on real life locations
-Great voice acting from the English Co-Driver Phil Mills, all of the throat clearing and changes in the tone of voice to sound more scared when the car is being thrown around a lot/ moving at speed adds to the feel a lot.
-Much more rallycross content than the first game (granted rally is what most people play for)
-Plenty of cars and rally locations with all DLC
-Good graphics

Overall the game is great but the listed problems warrant a negative review.
Handling is great on both controller and wheel and there's not really any other rally sim substitute other than RBR which is from 2004 and no longer sold

This is a positive review set to 'negative' because singleplayer can't be played offline and that's unacceptable.

I picked up the GOTY edition for ‚Ç¨8 on sale. Well worth it but an always online game isn't worth any more than that because when they stop hosting the servers you won't be able to play it anymore.

After comparing to DR1 I uninstalled DR1 and moved that into a library category called "recycle bin". I'd call it DR 1.5 rather than 2.0, or basically what DR1 should have been.

The FFB got a lot of hate but (nowadays) it is much better than DR1's and there's no way I'm going back to that. People say DR2 is harder but with the FFB no longer working against me and all forms of logic I have much better control of the car. DR2 also looks a little better, has way more cars and other content and a much improved menu system.

Unfortunately the leaderboards are effectively useless. You can't filter them to list just the times driven without assists and cutting the track is commonplace. This kills any desire to improve your times to get e.g. top 100 or top 10. Always online also sucks but it isn't worth sticking with DR1 just because of that. I do have a great internet connection and it hasn't caused any issues for me thus far.

I like the improved damage model as it forces you to adjust your speed to stay within your capability to control the car. It's very easy to get a puncture though - or in US English, a flat tyre. If you aren't a very experienced simracer you'll have your work cut out for you to learn how to not hit a tree every minute. It's not *quite* a true sim like Richard Burns Rally but still a very, very difficult game. It's sweaty. It takes a lot of effort and focus and therefore, energy. Not the game you play when you want to relax & just game.

When I was little my dream was to become a race car driver after playing Need For Speed Underground and Need For Speed Hot Pursuit 2, allowing my appreciation for driving fast and turning even faster, to begin to grow.
Little did I know that those dreams would become true in the form of this insane, beautiful, challenging, rewarding game.
The driving experience here is so visceral and extreme that my glutes sweat and my heart pounds...
I've always wondered what it would be like to drive unrestricted on narrow roads/paths through the woods and here I can experience just that without the fear of death or injury...though the realism and danger are what make these types of things most enjoyable, the simulation is good enough to where the threat almost feels real too.
All in all with a Logitech G29 wheel, pedals, and shifter (yes I'm starting with the Lancia Fulvia HF and it is an absolute JOY to drive), the gameplay is so much fun and immersive. The force feedback connects me to the vehicle and the surfaces beneath me, something that flight sims (I'm more of an aviation guy than a car guy but still) just can't give...I'd say the experience is much more intense here as #1 you are quite literally on the ground and can FEEL the relative velocity, and of course #2 you can feel every vibration/shock/grip/rock-in-the-road/bang/crash/slam on your hands and it is SIMPLY AMAZING!
Nothing is as satisfying and taking a turn at the exact required speed/angle/timing, and accelerating outwards, zooming through a narrow gateway and out into a straight away into 4th gear, while the New Zealand countryside flies past in all of its glory.
I have so much more to experience here and I'm only getting started, in general I am so happy to join this wondrous realm of sim racing!

From the authentic sounds of the wide selection of cars, to the sounds of environment ( different types and combinations of snow, dirt, asphalt, and gravel ), as well as the tuning and tire set-up capabilities, makes DiRT Rally 2.0 a fun challenging sim racer for both those new and old to the genre.

This is a game I play for the feel of the physics primarily. It's my favorite game for entering the flow state. You are constantly adjusting your vehicle's position in an inherently unstable  often-slippery environment, and it requires full attention to do well.
    I like games where you are rewarded for making decisions on the fly, and this game does that. Correctly deciding your speed when approaching a turn, when to start the turn, whether you handbrake, what gear you're in, etc, naturally results in a higher position in race results, as there are a lot of opportunities for mistakes throughout a race. This is all to say that It's a different style racing game that puts emphasis on keeping your car intact and staying on the road. I feel like I'm always flooring it in other racing games, not being rewarded for throttle control. I suppose this is why racing sims exist lmao.
    Anyway, this game rules, and it's DIRT cheap hehe

Jumping rally car physics feels pretty good.

Career mode is bad, can't turn off damage completely, and there are night stages, so if you broke headlights, it's impossible.
For me, this means the game isn't fun enough, as a beginner in sim racing/rally, I'm always in the bottom 5 of the championships, gets boring and frustrating really fast. You can create custom championships and bot "difficulty" can be changed, so there is at least some sense of success (I set it so I place around ~10th and I have a carrot on a stick then)

Time trial is good, you can restart as many times as you want, and you can practice and improve.
It would be a very nice UI feature to allow practice of any track+time+car+weather combo with a few button clicks for career or daily/weekly/etc challenges.

As a rally sim, Dirt 2 is GREAT! If you are into this, I DO recommend it. Arcade players play something else, or stick to time trials, and dip your toes into career later.
I really like how this game gives force feedback on the steering wheel, it helps to feel the car a lot.

edit after 34 hours of playing:
there are still grudges I hold against the game, such as the missing option to turn off damage so I can simply drive and learn the map+car (I don't care if those runs wouldn't end up on the leaderboards); this mostly means headlights at night, and punctures - I'm fine with breaking the rest of the car when kissing a tree, don't misunderstand me.
There is definitely a "git gud" aspect of the game, the difference between 1st place and retirement can be rotating a car too late or mishearing a call. As I definitely have improved over the last 20 hours, my experience improved as well. I keep the negative review in place for the time being, but at this point a simple "yes or no" isn't enough. For arcade players who just want to drive around on dirt and have fun, this game isn't gonna cut it. For sim racing players, rally fans, and ppl with lots of time on their hands (and willing to practice a lot, watch guides, etc.), it's an excellent value for your money. You have options to choose from, never really forced to do anything.

edit after 55 hours:

I just tried VR mode, works well, however it does require a high-end PC to run smoothly on high settings, and medium is... a little low. I have to emphasize that VR mode is good and fun, I can peek at the pace notes, I feel more immersed as I look at Phil and yell him silly things. Also, somehow the car feels better to drive around. Small bumps and dips are way more visible, the higher FOV helps you precisely control where your car is.
Crashes are not fun, though :) I am sensitive to motion sickness, but VR in this game is really pleasant - when it's not lagging - and I feel perfectly fine after playing 40-50 minutes. (yes, my brain knows that when driving a car, I sit, that certainly helps)

The VR experience, combined with the fact that I keep coming back to and enjoying the game, makes me change my review to a thumbsup.

I still hold grudges because I can't turn off damage when I just want to practice a stage.

To be fair, i bought this game (again) knowing what i was getting into for the absolute minimum amount of money. On first startup you're forced to waive all rights of ownership before even being allowed to play, and singleplayer does NOT work offline.
In fact the only reason i bought the game at all is because of its VR support, which works really well. I come back to this occasionally because it is one of the only racing titles that gives you the proper sense of immersion as well as a lower amount of time spent in menus than simracers often force you to. I never stick around for long though, because it usually takes less than a single race to completely crush my spirit, and the rally series does not take kindly to restarts.
About the driving itself tho: i drive, and i have driven the regular joe versions of some of the cars portrayed in this game (one or two even on dirt lanes, through woods, slightly too fast) and i refuse to believe that this is a realistic portrayal. Regular cars are not as difiicult to control as this game makes them out to be, even if boosted to the eyeballs and with straight-cut gears and everything.

In the end i'll settle for a love/hate relationship, which is still a lot better than being bland, but if you are on the fence i'll say that the EA publisher antics mean i can't recommend this to anyone but the truly masochistic.
