Let me say that this is the best racing game to date imo. I say game as I am tired of the whole "sim" debate. Unless the so called "sim" enthusiasts are using a 25K plus hydraulic cockpit designed for "sim" racing, its just a game. I have severe nerve damage and health issues and I am consistently in the top 500  (most times in top 250) with a Xbox controller. Owned expensive wheels before but it has never been like true driving to me.

Buy one of these or another brand for 25K then brag about your sim racing: https://www.cxcsimulations.com/purchase/

With all that said, the pathetic ridiculousness of RaceNet from day 1 has finally made me post a review and stop playing. I love the game, but CM has done so much crap to tick off their customer base and Racenet is not helping. Its so pathetic that it can't even keep cheaters from getting unheard of top times. They need to do away with it being tied to every function of the game, every click, every menu, every screen. To make matters worse, they throw all their other games on to this craptastic system and ruin it for everyone. I am not the only one complaining about this consistent issue. Read the discussions, here, and elsewhere, people are sick and tired of the broken Racenet and CM's inability to do anything about it. I have a 500Mb connection and have no issues with any other game or streaming service.

All they care about is selling more DLC instead of fixing what has been broken from day one. IMO stay away from anything from CM they are a shell of what they used to be like so many others. This game will cause you more aggravation than joy  and its not worth your money.

If they ever actually fix RaceNet and you can deal with the craptastic DLC and season crap they pulled then I would say go for it. As I stated it certainly is the best racing game when it works properly.

Get yourself a good wheel because this is NOT an easy game. You're gonna want every advantage you can get. Maybe there's some assistance options, but this game is meant to be a simulator and really shines there. Once you tweak some settings and get the game feeling like you want it and once you get some practice in, nothing else really compares to the sheer adrenaline you feel when man-handling your wheel and every bump could mean disaster during a race. If you're into racing games I highly recommend this game. It certainly helps it's one of the only ones I know of that does Logitech's Trueforce well if you've got a wheel with that.

Overall I highly recommend the game, but it is not easy. As I said, maybe there's some accessibility options to make it more like an arcade racer, but imo you're really missing out because the sim difficulty/realism is what you're paying for here.

Dirt Rally 2.0 is a magnificent game. This game I just started playing recently has opened a new world of racing simulators for me. This game is a game based on the history of WRC (world rally championships) and follows your career as you progress through the ages of rally-built racecars. The game-playing mechanics are incredibly hard but based on a very realistic scale of how it is to drive these cars. As for the graphics and scenery they can be anywhere from a game from the 80s to a professional photographer‚Äôs pi√®ce de r√©sistance. Turn off all HUD
Listen to co-driver only
Interior view only
Turn off all driving assistances (automatic gearing is ok)

I have spoken. This is the way.

The best modern rally sim out there.

-Incredible audio (engine sounds, tire noise, dirt hitting the chassis, etc.)
-Large selection of locations, stages, and vehicles (including historic FWD, RWD, and 4WD, Group A, B, etc.)
-Traditional stage-based rallies as well as rallycross
-Daily, weekly, and monthly challenges

It is punishingly difficult if you are used to arcade or simcade racers, especially traditional circuit racing with very wide tracks. By comparison, there is less traction, way narrower roads, and of course fixed object obstacles often only feet away from where you must drive. But all of that makes it so much more rewarding when you get a clean stage in. I put in the first 25 hours on my Steam Deck and the next 25 hours (so far) on PC on a sim rig. I still play on the Deck sometimes when not at the house and am only marginally faster on the wheel, although it is more fun on the wheel of course.

It runs beautifully on the Steam Deck, despite being "Unsupported" at the time of this writing. I run it on Medium with a rock-steady 60fps but it will also run high/ultra settings locked at 40fps, but the visual difference is minimal on the Deck's screen, so I prioritize frames.

10/10 would recommend, and I can't wait for the CodeMasters WRC game (hopefully) later this year.

Fun now that I got VR to stop crashing w/ AMD graphics card. go to My Games>DiRT Rally 2.0>hardwaresettings and find the vr hardware settings xml file. Change the value for "fullscreen" in the file from "1" to "0".

Dirt Rally 2.0 isn't just a game; it's a heart-pounding, dirt-spitting symphony of adrenaline. From the get-go, you're thrown into a merciless world of rally racing where every corner feels like a life-or-death decision. The precision required to conquer these treacherous tracks is both infuriating and addicting.

The realism here is off the charts. The way your car hugs the road, the dirt that kicks up with every skid, and the dynamic weather that turns a serene forest into a mud-soaked nightmare ‚Äì it's all uncannily true-to-life. The engine roars, and I can practically feel the vibrations through my controller. Speaking of controllers, don't even get me started on how much better this is with a proper wheel setup.

The career mode's progression is a masterclass in keeping you glued to the screen. From the humble beginnings with underpowered hatchbacks to conquering the iconic rally cars of history, the journey is a thrill. And let's not forget the online challenges ‚Äì they're the ultimate test of your skills against other speed demons.

If you're into rally or just seeking a white-knuckle racing experience, Dirt Rally 2.0 is the ultimate fix. It's not for the faint of heart, but for those who dare, it's an exhilarating ride that'll leave your palms sweaty and your heart racing for more.

Write a review for DiRT Rally 2.0

The game at it¬¥s core is good but it has some issues.

Rally stages are procedural what it means is that every rally is different but also in a single rally you will come across the same U turns, 1, 2 etc. This isn¬¥t bad in it self but Codemasters have screw up the co-driver.

The co driver is a mess, he calls the turns very late sometimes so when he is telling you about a 1 turn (very tight, slow corner) you are already flying down a cliff or you are hitting the apex and it is already too late. You can configure it to call turns earlier but it is not enough. Also there are some wrong calls, him telling you about a 5 turn but he never told you that it was after a minor jump so flying you go again. It gets very frustrating. There is also the 5 turn that is more like a 4 or a 3. What the codriver thinks is a 1 2 3 4 5 or 6 changes depending where you are rallying so you never know. He also calls turns that are barely there and you will be left scratching your head as to where was that 6 turn he called a while ago and of course you will crash because you don¬¥t know what to expect ahead of you.

Maybe you think you can put up with the crappy codriver, how about an always online DRM service? Dirt 2.0 has you covered. Nothing like losing the progress of an offline championship because it didn¬¥t match up with the online save they have on their severs. 2 hours of my life down the drain. The game is more of a "communicating with server simulator". At the start of the stage it checks the server, end of the stage, check the server, want to check your cars in your garage, let the game check the effing servers again. If you have an SSD you will be more time contacting the servers than on loading screens. And if you or their servers go down and it can¬¥t save your progress after a stage you are effed, no local save for you my friend you might as well not raced that stage.

Physics are good, but it is ruined by the codriver, the only way to be very fast here is to memorize every single type of turn and all the tricky bad calls.

Do you enjoy the enticing nature of driving recklessly, swerving in-and-out of heavily wooded areas, almost as though you're fulfilling an early mid-life crisis, on the thin and narrow road to death? If this question provokes a stern "Yes!" from your dark and depressed soul, then do I have the game suggestion for you! 
Let's be honest, fellas. All of us have wanted to satiate that twisted, primal fantasy of taking our grandma's 1998 Toyota Camry out rallying and demolishing its undercarriage in the process. It's a part of man's innate nature to feel the wind smacking us in the face going 90 miles per hour, down a winding, wooded road on the mountainside, with nothing but the smell of pine trees and motor oil being siphoned in-and-out of our nostrils. Unfortunately, some guys named "tHe BoYs iN bLuE" aren't particularly fond of us true-blooded patriots driving like the good lord almighty intended. Fortunately, this preposterous removal of rights is about to change. 

You're no longer alone. They say recognizance of the issue means you've fought 50% of the battle. Now leave the other 50% to DIRT Rally 2.0. The cars in this game have 3 gears: fast, faster, & "wrapped around a tree with your co-driver smacking you in the head with a clipboard filled with pace notes"

I can resume my opinion with 3 words.

--- Communicating with Server...

They've ruined this game.
Get ready to wait, and wait, and wait, and wade through repetitive, boring and utterly useless cut scenes before and after every... single... race.

People rave about the game's physics being oh so realistic... No... they are not.
I've driven multiple cars through multiple snow storms... that is not even close to how a real car behaves in show.
If you slam on the brakes before a right or left turn, your car will systematically start turning right or left, without you touching the steering. That's not good physics... that's the stupid game getting in the way!
I don't have a force-feedback steering wheel which I assume, makes the driving a lot more difficult. They should have thought of that.
Some of the races are just ridiculously hard with a gamepad, and I mean ridiculous to the point of being no fun at all. Rear wheel drive Porsche, in the rain and mud, with a gamepad... just nope...

Some of the races are good, some are not, but overall the "--- Communicating with Server..." ruins it.
Play it.

Decided to give this game a shot after seeing it go on sale and boy am I glad I did. I spend most of my PC gaming time on driving sims and had for some reason avoided rally racing until I felt confident-ish with my ability on other Racing Sims (Assetto Corsa, ACC) as I've heard how frustratingly difficult this game could be. 

Honestly I'm glad I did this as the fundamentals of driving on the track help in training you on some key fundamentals i.e. when the car starts to lose grip and how it feels to regain it. Once you've understood what it feels like to lose grip on asphalt, get ready to ramp up the intensity and frequency of that sensation 10 fold, because Dirt 2.0 relentlessly hurls arm-flailing twists at you. In the wet. At night. On three tires.    

It's pure joy.

This is my co- driver. There are many like him but this one is mine. 

My co- driver is my best friend. He is my life. I must master him like I must master my life.

Without me my co-driver is useless. Without my co-driver I am useless. 

I must listen to my co-driver true. I must drive greater then my co-driver's calls who are also trying to kill me. I must drive before I physically hear the call.

My co-driver and I know what counts in the championship, not the rear punctures we suffer, the noise of our Group B engines, nor the terminal damage we make. We know that it's the drifts that count, we will drift...

My co-driver is human even as I, because he is my life, thus I will learn him like a brother. I will learn his weaknesses, his strengths, his ridiculously late/early calls, his chin and his stubble. I will keep my Co-driver clean and ready, even as I am clean and ready we will become part of each other 

Before the track, I swear this creed, my co-driver and I are defenders of the championship, masters of the tarmac, we are the saviors of my life 

9/10

Extremely solid even today, it's extremely rewarding if you are able to complete a stage fastest and with no damage. Even without a wheel it is manageable, but I'd assume having one is a plus for a lot of the fine adjustment to get good stage times. Competing in championships with hardcore damage while trying to finish on the podium is huge fun too. Often I've been in situations where I need to repair both my radiator and wheel geometry, trying to decide which to do repairs on. Do I fix the rad so I know I won't overheat or do I risk it to know my wheels are on straight? It's a pick your poison type of situation when you're knee deep into a rally. Other than game play the fact that you have t purchase tracks and cars separately is pretty lame. Buy the bundle on sale. Overall, very fun, and very repayable. Def Recommend.

Por lo que he jugado, que no es mucho, por ahora digo, me encanta! 
Tiene sus cosas, como que el copiloto es el ser mas in√∫til en la faz de la tierra  o que  el juego decide cuando dejarte usar los limpia parabrisas (aunque el parabrisas nunca se ensucia ) y que las luces no solo igual, se prenden cuando quieren, sino que son marca 3 fuegos (no iluminan un carajo).
El juego me encanto, 
-Los coches tienen su dificultad a la hora de conducir, pero no son tanques sovi√©ticos ni autos de pl√°stico. 
-Tiene eventos diarios/ semanales /  mensuales donde jugas contra otros corredores para ganar dinero (obviamente gana mas plata los top X , pero aun estando en ultimo (como yo =_) ) te llevas una buena tajada para seguir jugando y destrozando tus coches!!  ), 
-Los autos tienen un sistema de rpg donde mientras mas conduscas con este desbloqueas los planos de otros motores para "tunear" el auto (ni idea si cambia algo o no, pero me gusto el concepto ), 
-El auto es TUYO , a que refiero con eso?  hacelo mier si queres.. las reparaciones salen de tu bolsillo te voy avisando. (tranqui, porque para evitar un p2w / softlock el juego tiene el Lancia Stratos (creo que es ese) que se repara gratis y jugando un campeonato en solitario podes ganar suficiente plata para reparar y seguir jugando otros autos)
-Y tiene un modo offline, si, no sub√≠s de lv el auto ni ganas dinero, pero las reparaciones son gratis (si mal no me equivoco) y podes jugar sin problemas si el internet explota un d√≠a. 
Sinceramente un juego muy bien pensado y entretenido. Recomendado y te recomiendo agarrar la edision full, trae cosas interesantes, como un porche 911 que se conduce que si las ruedas estuviesen echas de jabon y un buen pu√±ado de pistas (fuera de joda, recomiendo la edision full =) )

Must have game for all type of SIM racers!
Enjoying every second of this game, you will crash a LOT, a LOT and that's where the learning begins! 
For anyone who is thinking of buying it, it's DiRT cheap for now make sure do get the DLC pack included! GOTY edition.
PS : I use Logitech G29. If you own G29, I will share the details of the settings that worked optimally for me. You can adjust "self aligning torque" as per your feel of the wheel, I keep it at 65 sometimes 70, I tweak this as per track/car. 

Keep the wheel settings in GHUB to default values ie 900 degrees rotation, centre spring strength 0 and unchecked. 

In-game Settings : 

Vibration & Feedback = On
Self Aligning Torque = 70
Wheel Friction = 0
Tire Friction = 0
Suspension = 65
Collision = 90
Soft Lock	 = 150
Steering Centre Force Enabled - On
Steering Centre Force = 100

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda
¬º tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¬º tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8‚Äì10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you‚Äôve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don‚Äôt leave them too long or they‚Äôll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

DiRT Rally 2.0 is the best rally game I've ever played.

This game goes on sale for a STEAL at just 5 freedom dollars every so often.
The depth rally has to offer is quite amazing, as you will learn the calls for every type of turn ranging from 6 (shallow) to 1 (tight) as well as square turns and hairpins - all of which much be handled differently based on preceding turns and the speed you approach them at as well as what comes after. Not to mention elevation, terrain, and weather differences. And there is also comprehensive vehicle tuning and tire types to choose from on top of all of that :)

It's a thrill, mentally and physically. It's a blast to play with just a controller or keyboard but I HIGHLY recommend purchasing a rig and wheel/gear shift/handbrake.

I loved Dirt 4 so much. It actually introduced me to a type of racing game I did not know I loved yet. It was a bummer to see that Dirt 5 didn't take the good qualities of 4 but after reading the reviews of this and reading that people love this game because it resembles 4, I had to check it out. Well, it is definitely like 4 and with some better qualities. But, also a much harder game. I would say this game is more realistic that 4 was. This game ups the punishment of damage done to your vehicle as well as some other factors. Dirt 4, you could basically do an entire sprint hardly using the breaks and take corners at mach 2 speeds but no longer in this (not a bad thing). Dirt 4 has a decent learning curve but this has a for sure longer learning curve to master even in a monster of a car and not just the shit boxes. Either way, this game is amazing and makes me wish Forza could figure their shit out and take some stuff from this. Easy buy.

Dirt 2.0 has the best driverability of any rally game I have played since Colin Mccrae back in 1998. I was a master at that game and loved how the car responded to your input. The Audi Quotto was a beast of cheat car or  special code car. Its no wonder Codemasters is behind this game. It can be absolutely tiring. But absolutely thrilling to and satisfying to play. Very difficult game.

If you like Rally racing, this is as close to the real thing I've seen.  I love Dirt 5, but it is more of an arcade style game.  DiRT Rally 2.0 is not easy to play when you first start, and I have to admit I found it frustrating at first, but there is a lot of great documentation and videos online that, if you use them, will help you a lot.

The tracks, racing conditions and cars are about as realistic as you can get.  Which means, every car needs to be setup for the track and your style of driving.  For example, jumping into your new Porche 911 Ralley car, feels awesome as you wait for the countdown to start.  Then you find it is way too powerful unless you know how to setup the car for the track and to maximize stability.  Even then, it was too much car for my level of experience so I went back to less powerful cars and once I set them up found that I was no longer finishing in last place every race. :)

One other tip, the best way to rack up your credits is to enter the Daily event as often as you can.  Yes, you may find that, for many of them, you don't have the car needed to enter the race, however, paying Steam (on average) 2.49 for the car you need is a small price to pay and now you own that car.

Dirt Rally 2.0 is an exhilarating rally racing game that delivers an intense and authentic off-road experience. The game excels in capturing the adrenaline-pumping nature of rally racing, with its challenging tracks, realistic physics, and dynamic weather conditions.

One of the standout features of Dirt Rally 2.0 is its impressive attention to detail. The meticulously designed tracks showcase a variety of surfaces, from gravel to mud and snow, each requiring a different approach and skill set. The game's physics engine accurately replicates the intricacies of rally driving, including precise vehicle handling, weight transfer, and the importance of reading the terrain. These elements combine to create a highly immersive and rewarding racing experience.

Furthermore, Dirt Rally 2.0 offers a wide selection of iconic rally cars from different eras, allowing players to step into the shoes of their favorite drivers and compete in legendary vehicles. The level of authenticity extends to the audio design, with engine sounds and co-driver instructions adding to the overall immersion.

The game's career mode provides a sense of progression, as players work their way up through various championships and events. The challenges become increasingly difficult, testing your skills and forcing you to continuously improve to stay competitive. Additionally, the online multiplayer mode offers thrilling races against other players, adding a competitive element to the gameplay.

On the downside, Dirt Rally 2.0 can be quite challenging, especially for newcomers to the rally racing genre. The steep learning curve and demanding nature of the tracks may frustrate some players initially. However, for those willing to put in the time and effort to master the game, the sense of accomplishment is incredibly rewarding.

In conclusion, Dirt Rally 2.0 is a top-notch rally racing game that delivers an authentic and adrenaline-fueled experience. With its attention to detail, realistic physics, and diverse car selection, it offers hours of thrilling gameplay for racing enthusiasts. While it may be challenging for beginners, the sense of achievement and the intense racing action make it a must-play for rally fans.

For all of us who don't understand the rally language, here is a quick beginners guide:

L, R: Left corner ahead, right corner ahead.

1,2,3,4,5,6: The number refers to the severity of a corner ahead. The spectrum goes from 1, referring to a slower, first-gear hairpin, to 6, which refers to a flat-out, sixth-gear sweeper.

+, -: Modifiers that adjust the above numbers slightly, giving the driver more detailed information.

: Opens and tightens, two notations that help describe an upcoming corner's intricacies.

40,50,60 ... 200: Numbers from 40 to 200 represent distance (in yards) between instructions and features on the rally stage road.

&: "And" represents a distance shorter than 40 yards.

->: "Into" represents a very short distance that requires the driver to transition directly from one action to another.

Cr: A "crest" is something you can't see over or a feature that will likely unsettle the car.

Jmp: A "jump" will make the car come off the ground.

/: When you go "over" something, you need to take action while going over or through a rally stage feature.

OC: A corner is "off-camber."

Slippy: Slippery section of road.

Grip: Section of road with a lot of grip.

Care: Difficult road ahead.

!: Caution means there's a higher-than-normal probability there could be a crash.

!!: Double caution means there's a higher-than-normal probability there could be a crash and that crashing will total your rally car.

!!!: Triple caution means there's a higher-than-normal probability there could be a crash that could kill you.

Hope this helps :)

Difficult, frustrating, a battle between your abilities, the car and the road conditions. I'm not very good at this game but when i manage to stay on the road and get most things right on a stage it feels great and ultimately the reward comes from just improving incrementally - stay on track, get a little quicker each time, take a short break to maintain concentration, listen to the pace-notes but don't follow them as gospel as you get more familiar with the car, your driving style, and the stage in question. Turn off all the assists, timers, visual pace-notes etc to minimise distractions from your driving and each time you improve get that little rush of dopamine as you realise you can drive after all! Then next stage get too cocky, wrap it round a tree or hit a carelessly placed log or something, wipe-out, rinse and repeat all of the above!

THE go to rally game at the moment.
Less hardcore than Dirt Rally (1), balances somewhere between arcade and simulation for rally games.
Decent graphics (not the best optimization tough), wheel and controler support, quite a few cars and a multiplayer mode.
Downside is no FIA WRC licensed stages/cars, somewhat clanky physics (both car damage and driving when colliding with obstacles), flat out boring Rally Cross and not that many stages after all (each event has like 4-5 "original" stages that are cut, remixed and reversed into more stages).
All and all, still worth buying on sale and playing, definately better than WRC series junk up to Generations.

This is the game that got me into realistic driving sims. I absolutely love it, but I will say that I think it's the most difficult game I've ever played (yes, tougher than any Soulsborne).

Once you're familiar with the controls and concept of the game I would recommend the following settings:

1) all assists OFF
2) manual shifting
3) turn off HUD pacenotes
4) first-person POV
5) set your FOV correctly (google FOV calculator and look for one that supports DiRT Rally 2.0)

Do you need a wheel and pedals? Eventually, maybe... probably. I myself use a controller, but I've hit a skill wall now that I don't think I can get past without these devices (I usually land in the top third to top quarter of players in events). So I do think a real sim rig is in my future. I do know there are controller players out there that are able to get in the top 1% on a regular basis, so it's definitely possible to play with a controller, but I would imagine it makes the game even more difficult this way.

Coming from the Forza Horizon games, this was significantly different. It took some time to adjust, but eventually I found it more rewarding, engaging, and fun than FH. Excellent entry into something closer to simulation.

Great rallies that challenge you to stay consistent and not rack up too much damage between service areas, with a selection of daily, weekly and monthly challenges that the whole online community can join in on. Watch as you jump 500 places up the rankings across stages as more and more competitors presumably take terminal damage and wipe out from the competition. A meta-progression layer rewards you with upgrades per car and for your staff to reduce repair times. 

I do recommend getting the DLC if you want to compete online though. Most challenges require the DLC stages and while you can take in any car from the required category, you will need to use credits won from participation in events to buy eligible cars. Playing the single player career mode will introduce you to each class from the easiest Historic front wheel drive cars up to the modern AWD vehicles, but by the time you've unlocked everything you'll probably be tired of the same base game rally locations.

I am a 54-year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing Dirt Rally 2.0.
I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing Dirt rally 2.0
In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours.
This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son
because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam
account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game
since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent some hours playing Dirt.
I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Playing video games
reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought
me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well.

I played this game for the first time without ever watching a rally. Codriver was at first annoying, but came to respect him after all of the times he said "don't cut", I cut and slam into a rock at 70 MPH. Think I got a good time, but them come in 19th place. Buy a nice H2 RWD car, spin out on every corner and proceed to switch back to H1 FWD. This game is hard and sometimes I feel like I want to break my steering wheel, but I keep coming back for more. Very thrilling, but DLCs add a lot to the game. I do wish there were more circuits base, though.

One con is the fact that you have to connect to the web in order to play SINGLEPLAYER, I have personally not had issues with this but many people report having connection issues.

Game is very anti-consumer, with basically all content updates being in DLC form. Not so much of a bad thing tough, since they are optional and you don't have to pay for them in order to experience the game fully.

Game starts you off with a FWD H1, which is nice because you get to learn with a car that doesn't have much power, but gives good control. Repair costs are free on base cars, but cars that you buy you have to pay for repair.

Steering Wheel highly recommended, pretty necessary for most racing simulators but just a quick note before you buy.

Dirt 2.0: A Thrilling Test of Skill and Precision

If you're searching for a racing game that pushes your limits and demands every ounce of your concentration, look no further than Dirt 2.0. This game takes the concept of difficulty to a whole new level, delivering an exhilarating experience that will leave you breathless and craving for more.

From the moment you start Dirt 2.0, you'll quickly realize that it's not your average racing game. The developers have masterfully crafted a challenge that will put your skills to the test. The difficulty curve is finely tuned, gradually increasing as you progress, ensuring that you are always engaged and never complacent.

What truly sets Dirt 2.0 apart is its realistic physics and handling mechanics. The precision required to navigate each turn, conquer treacherous terrain, and maintain control of your vehicle is simply awe-inspiring. One wrong move can send you careening off course, adding an intense level of consequence to every decision you make. However, once you start to master the mechanics and find your rhythm, the sense of accomplishment is incredibly rewarding.

The variety of terrains and weather conditions further elevate the challenge. Whether you're battling through mud-soaked rally stages, drifting across icy tundra, or racing under a torrential downpour, each environment poses its own unique difficulties. Adaptability and quick thinking are key to success, ensuring that no two races feel the same.

Don't feel intimidated by "simulation" tag. If you can race cleanly in Forza Horizon, that's enough for a start. Difficulty curve is mostly about learning to listen to your co-driver (unlike old DIRT games there's no minimap), and un-learning to keep gas floored at all times.

Bunch of tips for beginners:
[list]
[*]Starter car, Lancia Fulvia, costs nothing to repair.
[*]Do Daily/Weekly/Monthly events if you have cars for them. They pay bonus, so you'll make profit even if you're still bad and repairs bleed you dry.
[*]For a starter focus on getting to finish line in one piece. Even driving like an old lady is faster than consistent mess ups. As you get used to driving, you'll be getting gradually faster without noticing.
[*]If you keep getting distracted and making stupid mistakes, disable HUD so it doesn't take your attention from things that matter. Hood cam will help you focus on road ahead.
[*]It takes hefty impact to completely trash your car. Avoid smashing into things head on at full speed, and you'll be fine.
[*]If in doubt... slow down. Taking wrong turn, spinning out, or flying out of road will cost you a lot more time than playing it safe. You'll eventually learn, likely the hard way, which corners are not what they appear to.
[*]You can't steer or brake while airborne. Take jumps only if you're sure you'll land back on road.
[/list]

i'm no expert, but i've been playing rally games since the OG Colin McRae Rally on PS1 and this is the rally game i come back to more than anything else, even over ones released after. 

for the sale price nowadays, with the GOTY edition generally somewhere between $15-$10, there is just so much to dive into here. benefit of patience, i guess, as this game had mixed reviews for a minute due to the DLC making you pay for things that should have been in the game in the first place. but now? yeah, it's a no brainer.

the wealth of classes, biomes, and the rush of a season playthrough where you can't repair your car between rounds is enough to engage most for a while, but the additional challenges (including what basically amounts to an entire second campaign dedicated to recreating iconic moments in Colin McRae's career) really make this a heavy, feature rich experience.

as for everything else, you already know the deal: the game is hard as fuck because it's a fantastic rally simulation, demanding patience and focus and excellence. but the rush of knocking out a clean run with your time on top is fantastic, and a feeling i generally can only find in games like Trackmania.

in my humble opinion, a racing game like this that demands so much of you but then rewards you in spades with deep content and satisfying end results (plus beautiful replays to make you seem even better than you really are) isn't as easy to find as it used to be. which makes the fact that this fantastic rabbit hole is generally the cost of a fast food meal, or maybe something a little nicer if you get the GOTY edition, all the more satisfying.

even though many might say the physics are floaty, especially on gravel, i actually find that quite pleasant to deal with. tarmac/combined tarmac races are fun, but gravel is where its at! the game is very well optimised for many systems, and the dont trust the youtube vids about graphics: in-game the graphics on High settings 1080p is breathtaking at times, but in general its definitely a 9.5/10 (only problem being some weird AntiAliasing changes from exterior to cockpit cameras. (ps, i am actually giving this game a positive review from just 4 legitimate non-stop playing hours, this game is really worth playing if youre on a wheel)

Nice physics, terrible gameplay on wheel with shifter. Just terrible. Honestly I'm not sure if I've done something wrong with the setup or missed some additional setting options, but I've had two major problems with manual, that made the game unplayable.

1. Gears sometimes don't change if you release the clutch to fast. It's even understandable. While it's unforgiving and there is little to no feedback that it happened, I could live with it, if not for the second issue.
2. The engine cuts out CONSTANTLY. Unless you push gas (to high revs) and then release the clutch, you will be doomed to waiting some time for it to start again. And if you've driven cars in real life, it will probably happen again and again, until you switch to this zero-one mockery of a simulation.

I was really psyched for this game and I thought I will be getting some semi-serious simulation, but I've played arcade-like games with better shifter support than this. And I think it's just embarrassing for it to perform this poorly.

Dirt Rally 2.0 brings Rallying simulation to a better level with improved physics, the cars now feel more planted to the road and weight transfer has more inertia to it. Graphics are also improved but to me, the 1st game still looks better and let me explain why. 
The shading in the Dirt Rally 2.0 maybe be better but sometimes it looks to unnatural  and "game-ish" (a taste thing) also there's some shimmering regarding draw distance, an unpleasant effect like semi transparent meshes and  this shimmering affects the track also. I don't know how to get rid of it and at the same time not to tank performance to much. It really disappoints and affects immersion in a pretty harsh way because it looks cheap and out of place for a 2019 racing game (considering it have been patched and no more updates for it will be out) with 107 GB of space. 
The track degradation and improved physics  are really two key improvements over the 1st game and that's a great thing but I feel that Codies could've done it a bit better in some other areas like one mentioned and a better career mode played in OFFLINE mode!

It's a great package nonetheless, especially  for 5 bucks (GOTY edition). Recommend it for every rally fan out there!

Dirt Rally 2.0 is a thrilling racing game that immerses players in the world of rally racing. From realistic physics to impressive environments, every detail is crafted to transport players to the world of rally racing. The sound design is incredibly immersive, with detailed audio and in-game co-driver instructions. The dynamic weather system affects visibility and traction in realistic ways. If you're a racing enthusiast looking for an immersive rally game, it's worth checking out.

Great game to try rally sim. The game is challenging but doen't punish all of your errors as another sim like rbr would. There is a wild variety of car and category to choose from (from 70's to group A and B to nowdays wrc ).
The physics of the cars and surface is great, with each car/drivetrain having different comportement, but doesn't always seems to be on part with reality (tarmac feels very slipy, kind of likre gravel), but it is predictable enought to be able to adapt quickly and enjoy the game, without it being frustrating. There is many maps to choose from, but there is no possibility to import mods, after ~100h you will probably have tried at least once each maps.

Not entirely realistic (the stages have 8/4 sectors instead of the usual 9/5), but as far as sound/graphics/gameplay, it worths every penny.
PSA: Don't bother with the base game, go for the GOTY Edition instead.

I've never played WRC series so it's not for me to say one is better than the other.
So what is taking me to DiRT 2.0 and have no need to look around for another rally game?

Years after release it still looks good, with full DLC bought on sale, you get some credits to get you going and cars from almost every class so you can jump in from the start in daily, weekly and montly races.
Career mode can be hard at first, but like many have said.
Start slow, get accustomed to different surfaces, cars with different drivetrains and build up speed over time.

Community is still alive and kicking, there are clubs you can join, connect with other players and have your own championship.
You can level your staff, yes you get staff that speed up and lower the cost of repairs after you crash, and you will, open tuning for your vehicles before certain stages.
There are tons of tuning setups for all the cars in combination with all stages that are in the game.
That all costs "money" so that little boost you get from full game pack really becomes handy.
And this was the thing that got me to stick with the game, because with tuning a lot of cars actually became drivable, I wasn't that bad after all.

So in the end, if you like rally, and can get the game on sale, try it out.
Who knows, maybe you get hooked as well and join in this crazy little circle of DiRT players.

Brand new to sim racing and this game is an absolute blast!!

Will note that I bought this game while it was on sale with the DLC bundles. But, if this game isn't on sale I wouldn't pay the full price of it. Based off other reviews it seems that the single player aspect of the game is limited due to the DLC additions. Overall the game has been fun to play even as a first timer into rally (as shown with 100hrs on record) but, there are some quirks here and there. There have been times using my G29 where the game will "lose connection" in a sense with my wheel/pedals and it'll drive itself into a wall. Along with the fact you have to have a rather steady internet connection to play the game. Lastly, there seems to be a lack of content in a sense of what to do, there are the challenges and such but if you only want to play solo career it starts to get repetitive over time. Other than those quirks it has been a good experience, I would still recommend the game despite the flaws but hey, it's a 2019 release game and it still holds up rather well.

I would recommend this game to everyone that loves racing sims and rally.

I don't actually like rally all that much, but this is one of the best pc racing games out there, in terms of overall balance of fun/realism/challenge/looks/content.

Plays really well with a controller, which is not something you can say for other titles towards the sim side of the spectrum. Turn ABS, TC and stability control to a light setting, and its a very fun, challenging game you can play on the couch. I didn't find I had to tweak sensitivity settings, but they are available. 
I love career modes, and this one seems solid, albeit a bit on the light side (light on "careeriness", not on content per se). But I'm just happy it's even there, you can't really expect anything from a PC racing game these days.
Oh it's also gorgeous and runs really smoothly. Awesome selection of classic cars. Good pacenotes. First game I actually enjoy rallycross in.

DiRT Rally 2.0 is an incredibly realistic rally game that offers players endless challenges. To really get a kick out of this game, I recommend playing with a steering wheel as it offers a much more authentic experience and allows players to better control their vehicles.

The game features several different modes such as career, a number of single-player races and also several online modes where you can compete against other players around the world. Career allows you to progress from the lower level competitions to the most challenging and important rally events in the world. You can modify, upgrade and customise your car to make it as fun to drive as possible.

Driving in DiRT Rally 2.0 is very challenging and requires precision and patience. When you play with the steering wheel, you will have to pay attention to every detail such as speed, traction, ground and other factors that affect your driving. However, the game is very well executed, so players can enjoy an authentic rally experience that is almost identical to the real world.

The game's graphics are also very well designed, with beautiful landscapes, realistic vehicle models and detailed effects such as tire tracks, dust and more. Engine sounds and other sound effects are also very authentic, making DiRT Rally 2.0 an unforgettable experience.

All in all, DiRT Rally 2.0 is a great rally game that offers players an incredibly realistic experience. If you're looking for a challenge and love authentic driving, then I definitely recommend playing this game with a steering wheel. Plus, the game is well balanced and offers many options to enjoy the world's greatest rally action.

I have been playing rally racing games since I had a Playstation (PS One Slim). You played a lot of V-Rally and Colin McRae Rally 2, those are the memories. Anyway, after Dirt 2, there wasn't a game that I enjoyed for a long time. But I really enjoy Dirt Rally 2.0. Pleasantly adjusted difficulty, the possibility of modifying cars and their settings. All modifications affect handling and every car is a little different.

However, the career and vehicle purchase system is somewhat confusing. I often get lost in which vehicle I already have and which one still needs to be bought. Managing your garage and team is simple but rather confusing. I recommend playing mainly with the steering wheel. I play on the Gamepad and I really miss the sensitivity of the brakes, acceleration or steering.

Anyway, 7/10.

I really have to hand it to these guys for making driving games with minimal fluff. No stupid cut-scenes, no story, no goofy objectives, no cringe dialogue. Just racing.

If you like a realistic rally simulator then this is the game for you. Although the tarmac physics in the game remain questionable, I absolutely love its dirt physics since its both fun and punishing at the same time. The variety of cars and really really eargasmic engine sounds is very appealing and I enjoyed driving the cars a lot. Those aren't the best aspects of it though, I would want to take note on how good the keyboard optimization is in the game. Since its a full on simulator game, it still offers viability for keyboard players and due to this, I could still set top 100 times on leader boards by just using a keyboard even with no assists! I'm very impressed on how well it performs on a keyboard which makes every other platform have a chance to conquer leader boards without needing an expensive sim set up. Overall, this is one of my most favorite racing games currently and I hope to Dirt rally 3 to be better. Honestly the only downsides I could note in the game are tarmac physics and the removal of Pikes Peak. I would love to see Pikes Peak in the game with this game's dirt physics but sadly that's never going to happen since the game is pretty much done.

Very fun sequel to my all-time favorite racing game that's difficult for me to recommend for a very specific reason. You see, this game theoretically comes with a single player campaign as well as rotating online challenges. However, the single player campaign includes the DLC maps as well as the vanilla maps in its rotation, and it doesn't let you play events with stages you don't own. As far as I know, there is no way to turn off DLC maps in the campaign, which means that you are literally unable to play single player at all unless you buy the DLC. And since the DLC maps are literally the same ones from Dirt Rally 1 that I had already put a ton of time into, I didn't exactly want to do that.

Now, it's not very expensive anymore, and I've satisfied myself just fine with the online events, so if you're into this kind of thing this game can still be a good buy. But this is just too preposterously stupid of an oversight for me to click the thumbs up.

Also it uses always-online DRM despite having no reason to, so the game's dead as soon as they cut the servers. Ugh.

Based on the previous work "DiRT RALLY", it is a rally game that adds elements of the previous work "DiRT4".Although it is possible to lower the difficulty and operability to some extent by installing TCS, ABS, stability control, etc., the characteristics of each machine and course are reproduced in the same way as an actual rally, and if you go off the course or collide with an obstacle, It's a tougher game than Gran Turismo SPORT, where you run on a wide closed course where your car breaks down, or you get penalties that put you a few minutes behind your rivals.In addition, the Pikes Peak Hill Climb in the previous work and the Land Rush (running on a dirt track with a truck) in the previous work are gone, and only Rally and Rally Cross are available.As with the previous two titles, Rallycross is accredited by the FIA Rallycross Championship, so real courses and models will appear.The differences from the previous work are as follows (currently).The previous work and the previous work started with a certain amount of money, and I could choose the first car from several types. You have obtained FF machines in the lower category, and you will start career mode with these two machines.Regarding repair costs, in the previous work, the prize money was deducted from the prize money after the tournament was over, but in this work, you can either repair the parts and pay the money before participating in the next tournament, or you can pay the money without repairing the parts. Now you can choose not to pay.The co-driver can choose from languages such as French, German, Japanese, etc. in addition to English (a man who seems to be British English), but the English woman who was in the previous work is gone.Rather than transforming the staff themselves into highly capable people, we invested in them and updated them.As for the course, the rally in the United States (gravel), Argentina (gravel), Australia (gravel and a little tarmac), New Zealand (gravel), Poland (gravel and tarmac), Spain (tarmac), snow and the stages of the previous work are so far. None (Monaco and Sweden will be added to Germany in a future update),Rallycross has some courses that have disappeared, but courses that were actually held such as the Catalunya Circuit and Silverstone have appeared, and the overall number has increased. is the emergence of Also, in the previous work, if you were in the lower category, the qualifying was omitted and you started with the semi-finals, but in this work, even in the lower category, you will be able to do it from the qualifying, so you will have four 4-lap races, and 6 laps in the semi-finals and finals. It will be in the form of doing two races.Also, in the previous game, low-difficulty tournaments didn't have rain, night courses, or long-distance courses, but in this game, it's raining at night from the beginning. Since it is a course over 10km, difficulty seems to have disappeared.Regarding the rally stages, the automatic creation that was in the previous work is gone, and the stages are pre-made like the previous work, but they are all well-crafted courses just like the previous work.Regarding the rally, elements from the previous work have been added, such as the car in front of you stopping on the side of the road due to a breakdown, and even after reaching the goal, you have to stop in front of the marshals to finish. Also, in the previous work, the sky was somewhat bright even on the night stage, and even if all the lights were broken, the road could be seen, but in this work, there is a midnight stage, and it becomes pitch black and you can't see at all, and the tire is punctured. And burst, and in rainy conditions, the grip and maneuverability are lower than the previous work, making it a severe one.As for the machine, the 2010s WRC rally car that was in the previous work has disappeared, and the new machine of the previous R5 (WRC2) will appear instead, and the Hyundai will be replaced by Citroen, Skoda, and Volkswagen.In addition, old rally cars such as Volkswagen Golf, Datsun Fairlady Z, and Citroen DS21 have been added to the GT category, while new categories such as Porsche 911, Aston Martin Vantage, Chevrolet Camaro, and Ford Mustang compete. rice field.However, unfortunately, no Toyota cars have appeared, and Japanese cars are Subaru (Group A Impreza, All Japan Rally Championship WRX, Rallycross WRX), Mitsubishi (Group A Lan Evo 6, All Japan Rally Championship Lancer Evo 10), Datsun Fairlady Z only.The rallycross machine has been changed to the latest in 2018, and the machine from a few years ago that appeared in the previous work and the previous work is not recorded, but it appeared in the previous work and was not recorded in the previous work. The Subaru WRX has been revived as the latest model.No other 21st century WRC top-class machine has appeared so far. I look forward to the update.The setting is almost the same as the previous work, but for some reason it is not possible to distribute the driving force of the AWD machine (front 30, rear 70, etc.) (other LSD settings can be made). As a new element, you will be able to select tires, and you will be able to choose from four types of tires: hard, medium, soft, and wet. If you make it softer, the performance will improve, but it seems that the tire will be more prone to puncture when colliding with an obstacle (I don't know if it will wear out in normal driving).Regarding the setting, in the previous work, if you install a device that assists driving such as traction control, anti-brake lock system, automatic transmission, the prize money will decrease, and if you do not install anything, the prize money will increase, but in this work Gran Turismo and It has become a system where the prize money does not change even if it is installed or not.Regarding the price of the machine, it is basically the same as the previous one, the older the machine, the cheaper it is, and the latest machine tends to be more expensive. Group A and R5 cars are several times more expensive than you might think, but if you win a rally overall once in Group A, the price is affordable.The RWD Group B, F2 kit car, and 2000s WRC rally car that were in the previous work and the previous work are gone, but looking at the career mode score results, a driver riding a 2000s WRC rally car appeared, and in the update seems to be added.It's a small detail, but perhaps because of the American version, in the previous version, Center was written as Center, and Tire was written as Tire, so it seems that it was changed to American English instead of British English (however, the distance is in the metric system) is used by default, and it is possible to change the metric system to imperial system in the settings).Although there are many problems, the machines from half a century ago, such as the old Mini Cooper and Alpine A110, to the latest R5, R2, and rallycross machines are recorded, and stages (although there are few countries) and races The content of the game is well-crafted, and if you like rally games, I think it's worth buying.

This mixture should make about 30 cookies.STEP 7Bake for 8‚Äì10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.STEP 8Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.RECIPE TIPSFREEZING THE BISCUITSIf you‚Äôve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don‚Äôt leave them too long or they‚Äôll dry out.STORING DOUGHYou can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Dirt Rally 2.0 is a rally racing game developed and published by Codemasters. The game features a variety of rally tracks from around the world, as well as a wide range of rally cars, each with their own unique handling and characteristics.

One of the game's strongest features is its focus on realism. The handling of the cars is incredibly precise, with each vehicle feeling different from the next. The game also features realistic physics and damage modeling, which can greatly affect the performance of your vehicle. This attention to detail can make the game challenging, but it also makes it incredibly satisfying when you finally master a track.

The game's career mode is well-designed, and takes players through a series of events and championships, each with their own unique challenges and objectives. The mode is engaging and keeps players invested in their progression, as they earn money and reputation points to upgrade and customize their vehicles.

The game's graphics are also top-notch, with detailed environments and well-crafted car models. The sound design is also excellent, with the roar of the engines and the screeching of the tires creating an immersive racing experience.

Dirt Rally 2.0 is one of the many games that supports VR headsets like the HTC Vive, which can add an entirely new level of immersion to the racing experience. By using the Vive's motion controllers, players can steer their virtual vehicle as if they were actually behind the wheel of a real rally car.

Overall, Dirt Rally 2.0 is a must-play for fans of rally racing games. Its attention to detail and focus on realism make it an incredibly satisfying and immersive experience, and its career mode offers endless hours of replayability. Despite its flaws, Dirt Rally 2.0 is a well-crafted and engaging racing game that deserves to be experienced by anyone who enjoys the thrill of rally racing.

I can say that it is one of the best rally racing games currently available on Steam.

The game's graphics are stunning, with highly detailed environments that are both beautiful and realistic. The sound design is also excellent, with the roar of the engines and the screech of the tires adding to the immersive experience.

The gameplay is where Dirt Rally 2.0 truly shines, with a deep and complex driving model that requires skill and precision to master. The game offers a wide variety of rally cars to choose from, each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses, and players must navigate through challenging courses filled with twists and turns to emerge victorious.

One of the standout features of the game is its dynamic weather system, which adds an extra layer of challenge to the races as players must adapt to changing conditions such as rain and snow. The game's damage system is also impressive, with realistic damage models that affect the car's performance and handling.

The game's career mode is also well-designed, with a wide variety of events and challenges to complete. Players can hire and fire crew members to improve their performance, and must carefully manage their finances to stay competitive.

Multiplayer is another strong point of the game, with a variety of modes and events to choose from. The game's leaderboards also provide a competitive element, allowing players to compete against each other for the top spot.

Overall, Dirt Rally 2.0 is an excellent rally racing game that offers an immersive and realistic driving experience. With its stunning graphics, challenging gameplay, and robust career and multiplayer modes, it is a must-play for any fan of the racing genre.

This is the Racing game i keep returning to. It's the most rewarding driving game I've ever played. 
I started playing keyboard and eventually moved up to a wheel rig and finally to a VR setup. You can play this game in any of those ways and its still fun af.

Cons: Slippery and somewhat unrealistic physics, Always online requirements, weaker force feedback, Rallycross online doesn't have collision

Pros: Slippery and somewhat unrealistic physics, all locations have an unrivaled amount of quirks and features, graphically beautiful, Sound design is phenomenal, Cars all have unique engine characteristics and handle VERY differently depending on engine layout and drivetrains, VR is native and well made, and there is a ton of content.

This game is very hard. The slippery physics punish late brakers Without mercy. I genuinely feel like playing this game made me better at games like ACC and WRC because of the habits that it forces you to develop. I will say that I've never experienced a thrill in a video game greater than sitting cockpit Sliding sideways at 90 mph down a narrow lane in Scotland and somehow ending up on the other side of it alive. Phil Mills is also the best Co-driver in rally and I kiss him on the cheek before every stage for good luck. As far as a racing game goes this one is the whole package and I'm probably going to play it for years to come.

I was one of those people who read through the "do not recommend comments", seeing a lot of people complaining about always online, bad force feedback and lack of VR (it does have VR support now), I don't use wheel and I thought I wouldn't mind always online single player.
But boi was I wrong, after spending more than a hundred hours in the game, the sluggish UX is really getting to my nerves, everything you do in career the game needs to communicate with the server, and the process is far from fast. And worst of all, CM if you want to make it all online, FIX YOUR DAMN SERVER, my championship has been reset 3 times in the past 2 weeks, and considering how much time each championship takes, it's just frustrating. 
Do a quick Google search you'll see this problem dates back to the launch of the game, the fact that this problem has been acknowledged for so long and still exist, is just not acceptable.
It's just a shame that small problems like this constantly overshadow the amazing gameplay, it's like they had the chance to make a perfect game, but no we had to add in some flaws because reasons. I doubt this comment will make any differences, since I'm already late to the game and the game is already sold so well and highly rated, why would CM care about a comment from a single user after so many have already failed?

Edit: Just happened again, after 55 stages, only 5 stages to the end of the championship, reset again because of discrepancy between local save and server F***

Edit2: 6/23/2022 Championship reset again. 5th time since I purchase the game

Edit3: 6/26/2022 Championship reset

Edit4: 6/29/2022 Reset, am I doing something wrong? or the game is just broken?

Edit5: 7/17/2022 FYI the problem didn't just disappear, I just gave up career mode at this point, I only play daily/weekly challenges, which is still a ton of fun and challenging. What pissed me of again is that the time trial mode, you know the mode that records your best time and updates to a worldwide leaderboard, one of the only aspect that make sense to connect to server, DOESN'T RECORD YOUR TIME half of the time, imagine pushing yourself to the limit avoiding the tiniest mistake, and finally finish with a personal high score. Yeah the game just says F you and ignore it half of the time, the inconsistency is just.... Why is this even a problem codemaster?

Edit6: 2/16/2023 Gave the game another chance, started playing championship, play through 4 stages, turned off the game to take shower, came back 40 minutes later, started the game, "championship has been reset  blah blah"... great job game.

Edit7: 2/23/2023 Man, I was so close to finishing a whole game and then it strike again... I think I'm done with the game, it's fun while it lasted, but it's also frustrating and a waste of time when problems that shouldn't even exist hits you, CM knew about these complaints but they chose to not doing anything about it. For anyone reading this in the future, don't buy this game, not because it's not fun, but we shouldn't support the company making these kind of decisions

Eagerly waiting for the next installment. If you prefer sim to arcade, this is currently the title to pick from the Dirt line-up. 

[i]Do you need the original Dirt Rally?[/i]

DiRT Rally 2.0 lacks the HIll Climb mode (2 time-trial runs up, Driver-only) from the original game. If you'd like to take historic and more modern cars up Pikes Peak (both dirt and semi-paved) options, then you'll want the original game too.  There are a few cars in the original that weren't included with DR2.0.  The rally areas are all included in DR2.0 with Monte Carlo getting an overhaul on its surface. If I had to pick one, I'd pick this game. The original often goes on sale at the same time for a pretty low price though, so if you have the means to pick up both, I would for the Hill Climb mode.

[i]Do you need all the DLC for DiRT Rally 2.0 or just the base game?[/i]

I recommend everything. At a minimum, you want the DLC that adds all the rally areas. This is especially important if you want to play the online events (daily / weekly / monthly community challenges), or if you want to join a club.

[i]I heard the online-only format of the game causes problems - Is that true?[/i]

When the game launched, and when DLC originally dropped, there were some hiccups with the online requirement. However, I have not faced issues with that since.  

[i]What game modes are there in this?[/i]

A lot...Some highlights are below...
‚Ä¢ Rally career mode where you pick the class of car and AI difficulty increases as you progress through seasons. Rally is a single car on a stage at one time, with a co-driver providing notes about upcoming turns and obstacles. Damage to your car is carried over from stage-to-stage until you reach a service interval where repairs can be made within a set time period. Stages can be dirt, snow, pavement, or a mixture of all of the above.

‚Ä¢ Rallycross career mode. Similar to the above, but with rallycross.  Rallycross is multiple cars on a closed circuit, doing laps on dirt and paved surfaces. Strategy comes into play with timing your Joker lap, which is typically a long path around a portion of the stage.

‚Ä¢ Daily / Weekly / Monthly events competing against times set by AI or real-life drivers around the world in a cross-platform environment.

‚Ä¢ Time Trails - Pick a stage and a car and see where you rank against drivers around the world or your own ghost.

‚Ä¢ Clubs - Join an existing club or start your own where events can be scheduled, stages and conditions can be set. Aside from community events - This is my favorite mode as it allows my extended family to set up events where we challenge each other, and are able to play as our schedules allow (rather than trying to all be online and available to play at a given time).

‚Ä¢ Colin McRae challenges - Try your hand at scenarios against AI competitors. There are a lot of these to do. Some are 1 stage, others are multiple stages. You may need to finish in the top 4 with a heavily damaged car, or you may need to come in first even after getting a 10-second penalty, or you may need to finish a series of stages without damaging your car at all. You can set the difficulty in this mode.

There is no better game out there on PC that feels this good for the type of game that it is. When I first started I was on controller, and even then was having a blast. (I recommend turning off all assists, and as many hud options as you can. They can distract from driving well and immersion.) 

Then I got a wheel, a logitec g920. And will be trying a g923. The feed back is amazing once ya get It tuned. Stock settings are a bit over the top when ti comes to force. In a later review I will post what settings that  found I like. One feature that blows my mind if your wheel supports it is the game's SOFT LOCK system.

If an old car, that had far more rotations in the wheel you will have to use the same exact ratio. Well on new cars that is not the case. And per that, each car is set to it's real life steering set up. This extra bit was so fun to experience. 

More to come

This game is not the Dark Souls of racing games; rather, it's the Call of Duty of rally games.

really nice graphics, great car sound, models and decent physics; I often found most of the cars very sluggish and unresponsive despite different tunes n such. obviously within reason. As your're on dirt it is expected to be that way but I felt for me it was more then what was perhaps warranted. at times cars can be extra skittish and jumpy and some of the clip detection on things can be a little unforgiving. Ie gently clipping a post made me roll. if you can look past the smaller stuff then its pretty up there.

Dirt 1 is objectively better in most areas, but thanks to the mechanics around tyres, and a mostly nicer HUD, and the fact you can't buy Dirt 1 anymore, all of my friends play this.

Why is my Single Player game saved online? Why is there no tutorials or explanation for most things? Why is the music worse? Why is the career mode substantially worse?

I'll give credit where due. I got this for the Steam Deck, and it works great! But bear in mind that you'll need to be online to play career, and it is a 100GB download. Dirt 1 is a far better game for playing on the Deck without wifi. But... You can't buy Dirt 1 anymore... =/

Dirt Rally 2.0 is definitely a fun game, and yes you can play it with a gamepad. It is challenging but not frustratingly so, there is a learning curve but you can see yourself gaining skill as you advance through the races. The best rally sim around besides maybe Richard Burns Rally. The dirt, gravel, and ice/snow physics are very good. The game is great at letting you get behind the wheel and driving cars from every generation up to 2019 R5 cars. The career mode is bare bones but does its job. However, the constantly cycling daily, weekly, and monthly challenges give a great chance to compare yourself to others. They also vary from single stages in daily challenges to multiple events across up to 5 different locations in monthly challenges, so there is good variety. On the negative side, the tarmac physics feel like the gravel physics with the grip turned up. They are still fun once you understand how to drive them. I recommend using toe in on all cars on tarmac. Tarmac does not match the other surfaces in terms of quality. Luckily only 2 locations are full tarmac and one is about half. The other negative is the AI in rallycross. The AI will react to you to attempt to block you to such an extreme degree. You can intentionally take a horrible line, the AI will block anyways and then miss the corner because of it. When the AI is behind you it is much worse. They do not react to you at all and will simply drive through you if given the chance. Tracks with joker splits near the start line will cause all sorts of collisions when the AIs and the player don't all choose the same route. 

Overall, I still highly recommend the game especially if your main interest is the rally side. It may be hard at first depending on your rally sim experience, but give it some time. Take it slower to learn and not crash, then start to send it. Don't restart every time you make a mistake and remember, "In order to finish first, first you must finish."
A decent simulator. Good game to practice driving techniques on. Tarmac physics is a bit lacking.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Dirt Rally 2.0 is the ultimate dirt-slinging, tire-screeching, rally racing game on the market. It's like playing a real rally race, but without the risk of ending up in a ditch.

The graphics are top-notch and the gameplay is incredibly realistic. You'll feel like you're really behind the wheel, dodging trees and jumping over rocks. The controls are tight and responsive, making it easy to navigate through the treacherous terrain.

But don't let the realism fool you, this game is also a hoot and a half. The crashes are so satisfying, and the sound effects will have you laughing out loud. I especially love the way my co-driver yells at me when I take a turn too fast. It's like having a real-life rally partner, minus the yelling.

One piece of advice though, make sure you have a good steering wheel and pedals setup. Otherwise, you'll end up spinning out of control and crashing into a tree (trust me, I know from experience).

Overall, Dirt Rally 2.0 is a must-have for any rally racing fan. It's challenging, funny, and incredibly addictive. So grab your helmet, rev your engine, and get ready for some dirt-slinging action!

This is the Elden Ring of rally games (I have not tried Dark Souls). Very unforgiving, but equally rewarding when you get that curve right (and DON'T crash into trees or aim successfully at the field). It takes a little while to get the settings right, and I recommend trying out the time trial mode, and even free ride mode to mess around and test.
I highly recommended using a controller with good sensitivity (I use an Xbox One Elite 1st generation), and it made a massive difference in terms of driving smoothly compared to using an Xbox 360, in my opinion. Using a wheel with FFB is probably the next level, but I don't own one, so I have no idea.

Dirt Rally 2.0 is, without a doubt, the greatest racing game I've ever played. At first I was turned off by how incredibly difficult and punishing it can be, but I found my enjoyment of the game dramatically improved once I turned off the progress bar on the left and the time differences at each section. Instead of getting frustrated 4-8 times throughout each stage, I simply drove as fast as I could without crashing. Funny enough, my times started improving after that.

Although I played a lot of this game on a controller, the other thing that dramatically improved my enjoyment was adding a racing wheel and pedals.

As far as the game itself, I just have to specifically call out the sound design. It's just spectacular, and the way your co-driver's voice changes based on the bumps you're going over or your speed, it often feels like there's a real person right there calling out pacenotes.
best experience

While not technically abandonware, there won't be any updating this game.  Yes, the online challenges are still active.  Yes, it's the best rally sim out there.  Yes, it is insane in VR.  And yes, it is not easy to git gud at.  The rallys run a wide gamut of real life stages from snow to loose gravel, tarmac and every other road surface out there.  It is insanely fun but unless it's on sale, I would not pay full pop for this as it's been abandoned.  It's a niche game and rally isn't as popular in North America same as GT racing but it is hella fun and once you get the basics, there are enough assists to get you going if you don't want the full sim thing and you can run it in complete sim mode where you have to deal with everything yourself in terms of setup etc.

Overall really poorly done, poorly implemented and will not be playing this game again.

This game is a simulator and is hard. If you're pretty good (talking like 1000+ hours of racing game xp Gran Turismo, Forza etc..), it will take 2-3 hours just to finish a race without crashing so hard you completely lose the race; this is at the lowest difficulty called "Open". At about 20 hrs you really start to internalize the co driver commands and directions and things start to flow. 

I enjoy this game, but it's definitely for those who value a high degree of realism. It takes a lot of focus and time to even become playable at the lowest level. At higher levels, a small lapse in judgement will cost you a 40 race series.

This is not an easy, arcade, Mario Kart style race game. If you've never played a racing SIM style game, it could take dozens of hours to make this game playable and many hours learning watching race theory videos to save trial and error figuring out what to do.

The steering, car physics, and stage design are detailed and immaculate, which contributes to a exciting sense of immersion, intensified only by the constant reminder that you are only a fraction of a second of a mis-input from a stage ender or enough damage to your setup to screw up your performance for the remaining stages, which gives the game a racing feeling of adrenaline that few other games are able to achieve. It instills a emphasis on a very delicate, yet intense balance between risk and controlled, learned caution, and the sheer dopamine rush when achieving such a balance for a stage is one of the most rewarding experiences in gaming, which I feel completely justifies the abnormally high amount of time and effort one would spend learning and intuiting it's mechanics. For its price (especially on sale), it is definitely a steal.

After DIRT4 I kinda lost hope in this franchise and unless they actually will fix this game, they have lost a long time Dirt / Colin MCRae fan. GG

2022 EDIT:

After buying all DLC on a sale for about 10 pounds and actually having access to the game, I have played it a bit more.
The cars are very floaty and there is no real connection to your environment.
The black mirrors and sound cutting out are fixed.
A large part of the tracks are still boring 6s and 5s, sometimes a 4 tightening if you are lucky.
After purchasing the DLC, some steam achivs do not unlock anymore.
I think that if you get the complete game and DLCS all for 10 pound on a sale, it is worth it.
But it still is certainly not better than DIRT Rally 1, that has been delisted from steam by codemasters.
After EA purchasing codemasters recently, I think it is probably best to forget about Colin McRae / Dirt series.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, after he got a thrustmaster wheel so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. This game... 

I love it. I honestly, very much love it. Everything feels great in this game, the surface slide, the torque of the engines, and sliding in AWD and RWD, it's all just amazing feeling. It's easy to sink a couple hours into this game without realizing it, and the competition can be as difficult or relaxed as you want it to be. There's a great selection of cars to take out on a great selection of stages, and the environments and racing itself never gets old. If Steam had a star rating system, this would easily get 5 out of 5 from me. The game runs butter smooth and looks fantastic too and Phil Mills does amazing work as the co-driver, as always. Would highly recommend this game.
