I've been playing rally games for 25 years and this is the most flip happy physics I have ever seen BAR NONE.  If you TAP a ridge, you WILL FLIP, GUARANTEED.  The ridges in this game are quite literally ramps.

What they did over previous rally games is make everyone extremely slow so that you try to take courses more conservatively, you can't endlessly restart and cliffs are ramps that flip you every time and hills are magnets, if you coast 10 inches off of a hill you will get sucked down.  You instantly get reset and penalized with time which means you have now lost the race, same for flipping.  Making everyone drive conservatively might sound cool and realistic, but it sucks the fun right out of the game.

I'm also sick and tired of rally games that think they are smart and clever for starting you off in the most absolute garbage, trash, snail slow 1960s euro-italian 4 speed piece of ---- that they could find, like how every time you beat a rally game it is your first time playing so they have to "teach" you again.  Dirt Rally 2.0 has less tutorial features which is fine, so they assume that you know how to play a rally game, so WHY start you off in such a ---- car?  I'm slaying opponents in Rally Cross by a factor of 30 seconds in a 5 minute race (because the car was made this millennium) but I can't drive the starter car you get in Rally for more than 20 seconds without flipping it.  I'm literally going to go make some youtube videos on rally games and show you how flip happy the physics in this game are.  Also, if you so much as tap a chicane (supposedly made out of bales of hay) your lights will instantly break, this is instant game over if you are at night.  They mount the lights on the nose of the car.  WHY is THAT in the game?  Mount them on the top of the hood.

Game's a joke and I would refund it if I could, but at least it was pretty cheap as I got it on sale.  I have been playing Rally games for 25 years and I have never played a game as flip happy as this.  Utter trash.

9.5/10

One of the best rally games you can every pay for.

What to expect:
A challenging rally game with stunning graphics, lots of content, and overall a fun experience.

Cars:
There are a lot of cars from the original rally cars from the 60's, to group b all the way up to rallycross cars. 
They look, sound, and run great.

Tracks:
There a lot of tracks in the base game featuring gravel, concrete, and tarmac. They all have their characteristics whether it be mud, logs, bridges and many other hazards. The tracks are interesting and fun, some can be very technical and have a ton of turns and some have more straightaways to get higher up on the leaderboard.

Driving:
My one problem with the driving is how it feels like you are driving a flying carpet compared to a rally car. There is not much grip. If you can get used to this style, driving is good and is a lot of fun. Powerslide through turns and drifting around hairpins feels great.

DLC:
There is a lot of DLC and every single DLC is great. Where it be new maps, new cars or the Colin MCrae expansion pack. I suggest you buy all 4 season passes when they are on sale. as you get everything (but 2 small dlcs) for around 10 dollars.

Modes:
There is a career mode which you can win courses and championships and get money to purchase better and faster cars. There is free mode where you practice your skills on tarmac, water, jumps, and gravel. There is a historic mode where you go through the different eras of Rally history, you can race for your Race.Net club, custom championship mode and finally the FIA RX championship mode where you partake in Rally Cross championships.

Pros:
Lots of base content
Stunning graphics
Great DLC
Great sound design
Good modes
Fun challenge

Cons:
Driving physics.
Most DLCs are small and should be free.

Rating:
Graphics: 9/10
Physics: 7/10
Content: 10/10
DLC: 10/10
Gameplay: 9/10

As soon as you reach the Master tier in career mode the game just stops being enjoyable. I'm not Sebastien Loeb, I just want to play a video game once in a while. Other than that the base game only offers 6 locations with 6 stages each and Finland is locked behind DLC which is borderline criminal. A shame because the driving physics are excellent and driving feels perfect.

You could argue that its a greedy move of the developers and that's hard to deny, but in that case, its 6 more countries many more cars for 5‚Ç¨ more. The Sweden DLC for example, initially very unforgiving with narrow roads, is now more fun as you're not constantly stuck in snow. What i want to say with this is that they did not just copy paste the rallies into part 2.0, but arguably slightly improved them.

Everything in this game just seems way more polished, the UI, the feeling while driving, so i can absolutely recommend this game, EVEN FOR CASUAL PLAYERS.

The only bad thing is the need to be online all the time...

Got the first Dirt Rally for free from some pack years ago and finally decided to play it. It's actually pretty good. Liked it so much that I bought this GoTY edition for $10 and it was totally worth it. It's a racing sim so don't expect Need For Speed type gameplay. In-fact getting around a corner when you're first starting out is an accomplishment in itself. It works well on controller, but I imagine a wheel would be even better. The physics are really well done, cars feel weighty and different from each other, but not overly heavy and hard to control. Newbies should start out with a 4WD car and gradually switch to RWD as you learn how the physics work.

Personally I liked Rallycross the best from Dirt Rally and Dirt Rally 2.0 really expands that aspect. Not sure what content does and doesn't come with, but this game has many more tracks and soooo many more vehicles available for Rallycross than the first did.

I also really like the new way the repair system works in Rallycross this time around. It felt like you had way too much time in the first game and it was just an extra menu to go through between races. This time you get half the time, 30 minutes, and multiple ways to fix the car. You have a standard fix which is a pretty detailed standard repair. You have a replacement option which takes the longest but completely replaces the part, these usually take 20 minutes or more of your 30 minutes so use it sparingly. You have a 'quick fix' this time which is much faster to do but is basically a jury-rigging for the part meaning it will work for the next race, but need replaced before the next race. This all adds up to a much more detailed and in-depth repair system where you're having to make tough choices and make sacrifices, which the first game lacked except in the most hardcore of crashes.

I still have yet to play any mode besides Rallycross but I'll try to update the review when I do.

If you expect a ridiculous mayhem such as dirt showdown or dirt 5, this is not the game for you.

But this is in my honest opinion the most approachable racing sim out there and I love it. And even though the game allows you to set it to be easy on you: I much prefer the more difficult presets. These cars feel great, when you do every shift yourself, when you drive without aids, when you try to do the ABS on your own. And even with just a controller and no force-feedback trough a steering wheel, the game gives you plenty audio, haptic and visual aids so you know how your car is doing.

My only huge gripe: the co-driver.

Don't get me wrong. He is - like everything else - a night and day difference between the already very solid co-driver in DiRT Rally 1.0. He has much more useful calls about the road geometry and he speaks them clearer and with more engagement so you are less likely to tune him out in the heat of speed.

But: his timing is sometimes just jarring. I've seen calls for a 4 turn (so something you kind of have to brace for, because it is relatively tight), that are more then 6 seconds ahead of the actual turn, witch only slows you down, because you do too much anticipation and there's also at least one call for an unseen turn 2 (so a tight corner you can't anticipate without a call) right after a long straight, that is 2-3 seconds ahead the actual turn giving you no time to react.

Wrecking a run because of such things is really frustrating and I'd love to have the option to fine-tune these calls during a trial ahead of the timed run.

best gaem ewer

Incredible graphics and engine-sounds!
The weather-effects (rain, sun, reflections) are so cool that I'm always waiting for the next rainy stage! This is also true about the night-stages, before Dirt Rally 2 i didn't like the night stages, because somehow i felt blind, despite the working reflectors. Here in DR2, the night stages are more visible, and also look better, so they are not so dead-playtimes than in DR.
The control is easier than in Dirt Rally, without any assistance is easier here, than with full assistance in Dirt Rally. Codemasters certainly decided to develop a game for a bigger audience, not just for the rally-experts or other masochists. So if You want to play, not to struggle with the physical laws, Dirt Rally 2 is here for the normal people too! :)
(But after 30hrs of play I see now, the control is not easier, it is the same, just the stages don't have those funny obstacles (rocks, logs, parking cars :) in every inch near the road, which were whacked our times in Dirt Rally, but the bad news is, the cars and the stages are insanely fast, so without obstacles, the reach of elite level is a tricky task! And as your speed grows, those tricky-funny obstacles will come back on the edge of the stage...
I read the negative reviews, and somehow i understand them, they are not lies. Either me think that DR2 is the perfect sequel of the legendary Dirt Rally, but how can You give thumbs-down? Please thumbs-downers, think again about how reasonable is to give thumbs-down to a game which is the greatest rally game of the present? Legitimate criticism is right, but a thumbs-down for this game is a strong exaggeration. Especially when we know, thumbs-downers will play this game in the next years too, as the thumbs-uppers will.

Pros:
- Graphics are wonderful, beautiful in bad weather and also in night stages. Sun-rays with rain are unimaginable before You see this beauty! :)
- Engine sounds - incredible 
- Rallylike long slidings - which were not available in DR1
- Thrilling speeds (really thrilling!!!)
- Each of the 6 countries have different road surfaces, and the difference aren't just in the colors and textures, but their grip, and the run on them are palpably different.
- The DLC locations - the classics - are wonderful! 4-5 EUR for each of them is nothing.
- Lifelike price for the mistakes in career mode - expensive repairs, irreversible terminal damages because of the not unlimited restarts
- Better gravitation effect than in DR1 - no moon gravity (edit > sometimes there is moon gravity)
- Wonderful replays
- Great to see the Class Leader's position on the progress bar

Cons:
- The RaceNet requirement in singleplayer is incomprehensible. I lost several good results because this "connection failure". Moreover RaceNet had an about 15 hours meltdown, while the players couldn't play with the Career mode - and this is totally unacceptable if i see my 115 EUR bill for this game+deluxes.
- My gamepad doesn't vibrate. After the big FF update, everything was fine, my gamepad almost blowed up, but after 2-3 weeks, it doesn't vibrate at all - only on 1 stage in 30 - that's why i know my gamepad works fine.
- Lack of english female assistant! ( How rude from Codemasters that they give us female pilots, but don't give a sweet female assistant voice who would guide us in the hard lefts and rights! )
- You won't see your car's whole appearance until You start the rally. You can see only the front view of your car, and You select a paint in this view, and later You'll regret it when You see it from behind - for hours until You complete a championship, because You can't change it between the events.
- Restricted options in volume settings. Why can't we lower some sound types below 50%??? This was the same in DR, and i hated it. I always have to ALT-ENTER and adjust my system sounds to DR1, and now I have to do the same with DR2... this is an unnecessary restriction.

Probably the best VR racing game on Steam. Great wheel support and works well with WMR. Runs great under the right settings in VR but you you definitely need a respectable rig for stutter free sessions.  I'm running a 5900x / RTX3080 on NVME and runs perfectly fine.

By FAR the best VR sim out there, everything feels tuned in and the immersion is out of this world good. I've always dabbled in driving sims and never thought much on rally, played Dirt 1 for 5 mins and decided it wasn't for me (not sure why). Then one day saw D2 on sale and thought I'd try it!!! It's been 3 days and 12 hours later.
OG Vive with lens mod makes this AMAZING. I understand there is the WRC game but with no VR I'm not even going to bother. The sound/ notes of the engine are crisp and tells you exactly what the car is doing.  I use a gamepad and this is really important the the sound of what the tyres are doing is my force feedback, giving the ability to apply more power or brakes. The graphics using VR on a 10900k, 3080 OC'd are excellent on high and I'm able to keep a steady 90fps with some dips at very rare and odd times (possibly background apps). My hope is that the next WRC which is being done by Codemasters (EA) will be VR supported too. I am now hooked!

This game is clearly the best rally sim out there and there are a number of reasons for this.
The car selection is fantastic as it ranges from thevclassic cars like the Mini to the modern beasts like the Ford Fiesta. The stage locations are equally brilliant as it includes locations which aren't in rally games much like Scotland and the USA which the WRC games don't get. Yes the stages are Codemaster's own work but boy they are a blast. It has the world rallycross championship license which is a superb inclusion and the track selection is spot on as it includes iconic locations that the world rallycross drivers race on. The setup screen has explanations to help you set up your car to your own specific personal preference (A stiff setup with a low ride height gives superior stability). You will crash a lot as it is hard but that is part of learning to be a rally driver. If need help there are driver aids to help you out.

lacks the variety of the main contender in the rally sim space (Richard Burns Rally, as carried on by community mods and support for the past 18 years), but is still a great driving experience. I've been playing in VR, and it's been a blast. the wheel feel definitely seems a little... i dunno. arcadey in some respects. it definitely feels like a magic black box of input going in and then making the car do certain things, like left-foot-braking just seems to flip a switch and the car magically wants to get sideways with ease, whereas in RBR, the physics seems to more precisely simulate each wheel individually and the results vary a bit when you do things like LFB or blip the clutch to get some oversteer. 

the wheel feel also feels kind of like it's in syrup... the FFB is strong, but it feels sort of sluggish and like it's over-damped. RBR has more jerky and sudden feedback to reflecting rough road/path surfaces and sudden forces like catching ruts, whereas in DirtRally2.0, everything feels very uniform and soft (still strong/firm, but like, mushy and smoothed out). 

still a very fun sim, and maybe an 8/10 on the realism as far as feel. the car tuning and setups are good without being totally overwhelming. weight transfer feels really good in the wheel force feedback, and it feels like it's easier than in some other titles to sense your speed on the track and stay within a reasonable speed for the space and conditions... some games, it feels like you just instantly go waaaay too fast without realizing visually or through the feedback in the wheel. 

I bought all the track/car DLCs in a bundle on sale, but haven't played most of it yet... but with all that, it should be a pretty nice bit of variety. base game probably leaves a bit to be desired though. Definitely easier to get into than some other sims as far as just installing, booting it up, and playing. didn't have to muck around with tons of troubleshooting to get all my controls to bind correctly or anything like that (although did have to set the binds up front).

Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game. I truly wish I could. However the pace notes are so fucking horrendous and there is nothing you can do to mod them to be correct, I do not wish the pain of anyone taking this game seriously. As if you even TRY to take this game serious you will QUICKLY find out that the pace notes are just way off. You will constantly get called out turns that are sharper than the codriver says, you don't get nearly as many cautions as you should, half the jumps are wrong either not called or called as a jump when they really aren't. These calls do not take into account your class at all. It's fucking horrible. If you go onto a track with an incredibly quick car, you better turn the calls to EARLY and just try and remember some of the shit, and if you jump onto the same track with a slow car well, better turn that shit to LATE and pray Phil doesn't fuck you up with an extremely late call on a hairpin or a "2 right tightens" but is actually a fucking hairpin".

It's a rally game and it doesn't quite suck BUT...

>there's a major issue of cars not wanting to flip back from being sideways on two wheels, there's a force keeping them this way
>a single russian modder could add perfectly fine rain simulation and wipers in Assetto Corsa...whole team WITH BUDGET called Code"masters" couldn't - it's a crappy gif in this game...
>colin mcrae very first race has major audio cutting issues because of the "retro" radio effect
>online races don't have horns...come on....
>online races also do not have physical racers on track, you start in the same backrooms dimension with NPC specators just like in solo play...only difference being that you see a timetable in the end
>a game from developers with, let's be real - infinite budget to create a [u] proper [/u] damage simulation STILL HAVEN'T DONE IT! "Hardcore" damage more like "slightly more" damage. Beamng manages great internal parts simulation (as a damage simulator should, but rally simulator should too, to more extent than dirt 3 tier...) Assetto doesn't really have internal simulation but even those beanbags managed to make a FUNCTIONAL CLUTCH SYSTEM! [b] this game doesn't punish you for not using clutch [/b]
>online only, it is well known that they will not survive as a company forever and, unless they release master server files, it WILL die one day. Yes! One day your money spent buying  this game will just disappear into void as this game will become unplayable thanks to the "great" choice of DRM... Remember that if people pirate your games, there's clearly an issue with it.
>so many tracks missing, it did get kind of repetitive even after 16h of racing, over which i only actually finished only two rally seasons. Where's Baltic rally tracks? Sure, Biƒ∑ernieki is cool but i was hoping to rip some Estonian gravel or more of Finland...the home of rally??? That's a very shameful oversight by these clearly western developers.


If you can ignore all or i guess most of the forementioned issues, go ahead and buy it [u] on discount [/u], otherwise wait or stay far away, get dirt 3 or beamng to fill your itch. Beamng does a great job at gravel rally simulation as the nonexistant tyre model does work nice off-road.

I'm just gonna make short review
Steering:
Dirt feels more realistic in car control and it's so damn beautiful for simulator enjoyer. Every car got their own characteristic and somehow feels different. While WRC every car feels the same. The only difference is only on the Power and Grip. If you gonna say oh it's because they use rally1 car the latest rally car. No you were wrong there is some other car that you can use as direct comparison like Subaru impreza group A or the group b monster. Every car in WRC just feels grippy AF and this make it easier and more less realistic but not necessary a bad thing.

Stage
Even though  most of the DIrt stage is locked in DLC when I play the stage it kinda feels the same. Of course some stage got their own unique signature like high speed bump of rally finland or tarmac sliding of rally Deutchland, but overall most of them kinda feels the same. Mean while in WRC every stage feels like got their own thing. 

One more thing that i want to discuss about the stage is Dirt rally feels more brutal. When the co driver said don't cut it means DON'T CUT. In WRC you still can cut few corner or find some sneaky shortcut.

External Factor(Graphic, Sound, Car):
More car in Dirt 2.0 and each of them feels different in every ways(Control, Power, Technology, Engine sound) the sad part is no historically accurate livery not all of them some car still got historically accurate livery like mcrae and 2000cc class(You can fix this with mod)car but the older one none and no latest Rally1 car like no 2010-Now rally car. There are some but in R5 class not the same as rally1 car. In WRC they got all of the historical and rally 1 car but in the end they all feels the same(engine sound,Control). 

In terms of graphic Dirt 2.0 is better

So overall I wouldn't say WRC is bad and dirt is 100% objectively better. In my opinion if you just a casual gamer that just wanna play rally go for WRC. But for people who appreciate realistic driving thing or simulator enthusiast go for Dirt 2.0 like no joke Dirt Control is much much harder than WRC

Overall I gave this game 9.25/10.
If only they add rally1 car and more unique stage like safari rally. i would give it 10/10 but nonetheless very worth to buy

[h1]VR Review[/h1]
Dirt Rally 2.0 was the rally game I came back for after the series went full arcade (firework phase). It went back to the roots and with good graphics to pair. Just before buying I got my first VR headset, I quickly noticed that VR + controller doesn't really work that well so I've invested in my first racing wheel as well. One of the higher end Logitech wheels + pedals and shifter. Mounted them with some wooden-build additions to my desk. Made sure my office chair was held in place by placing a table behind it. The true starter-setup.
Fast forward a full year later. I now own a racing seat, upgraded my VR-hardware. I've invested in Bhaptics suit + arms + head...

I'm in love.

Dirt Rally 2.0, with Trueforce √°nd Bhaptics is something else. Is it realistic? Nah, it's a game. But in real life I drive a Toyota Aygo, so really anything that can move faster than my real life car is a joy. Add some turbo injectors, four wheel drive and the idea that you can drive 200km/h through a forest and magically stay on track if you listen to your co-driver VERY well.

In VR this game is a whole different thing. I'm driving in full 5K 120 fps and I'd say this is about the resolution you want before you start seeing too much detail that will break immersion a little. I'm currently running the game near highest settings and I can still see the grass load in, a hundred meters in front of me. I currently do experience a glitch where 1/5 runs my headset disconnects (???) for a fraction of a second which can totally kill your run. More so annoying if trying to stay in the top 100 of the month. A glitch I only experience in this game.

I'll not go too much into depth about the realism of the surfaces you drive on. It feels realistic enough, yet it equally reminds you it is not. The snow+ice event in the mountains is a good example how a good racing rig will make you feel when you have grip, and when you lose it. Switching terrain feels a little off at times, but it is good enough. Sim-racing is getting better and better, but we aren't at the level reality provides just yet, so I'm not demanding it.

A side-not is that it is a little mandatory to buy the entire game + all DLC or the game will remind you constantly you don't own all the DLC. The DLC provides you with extra cars that allow you to try a couple of disciplines you might not have enough (ingame) money for.

Here comes my biggest gripe with the game, which is both a good and bad thing at the same time: progression. It is very slow. Racing a montly event will easily take up a couple of evenings. Reach the top 100 and you generally earn back three times what you've invested in repairs and maintenance. That is, if you are like me and you still flip your car every now and then. But you don't crash your car anymore. You just witness how a pretty car gets banged up to the point you start to doubt your driving skills... but you are 30 seconds below the fastest time, which is much better than the 3,5 minutes behind when you first start this game.

I've completely stopped playing the single player events and started to push myself to do online events most of the time. I've set goals to improve my leaderboard rankings, I've pushed myself to drive a little slower so I can finish every run. I've strategically upgraded my crew so I can get away with driving a little more aggressive when I feel like I can.

My biggest issue with this game is that all the maps are hand-crafted. Which is a good thing for a proper rally flow, but equally, I always felt like this game gets close... but equally pushes maps forward with dangerous parts your co-driver doesn't even mention. Which is something that started to bother me more and more. Callouts that don't really match the scenario. This happens in real life as well, but not calling out having to stay on one side because there is a blind corner straight after a jump, or not mentioning sticking to the left side of the road because the dirt mounts on your right will crash you completely... small details that would have been mentioned in real life.

The addition of VR + haptics make this game feel like you are there. My headset has noise reduction so I don't hear the vibrating steeringwheel + suit either. Driving over cow-bars has never been as satisfying as in this game. VR makes this game even better. In rally seeing depth is even more important to judge the curve of a corner or to spot a detail that might mess you up later. It will equally scare the crap out of you the first couple of times you crash.

So is it worth investing 1000-2000 euro's to enhance your racing? If you aren't looking to upgrade to a 10k racing rig but would like to experience something that comes as close as possible, without actually being the same hardware? Yeah... it is worth it.

TLDR; A great game, not too difficult to understand, therefore a great game to start with if you're new to the rally scene. 

I grew up with the Dirt Rally games. The first Dirt Rally game I ever played was Colin McRae rally 2004. And I loved it. Compared to modern games today, it's graphics certainly don't look good now. But at the time they looked great. 

I've been comparing Dirt Rally 2.0 against it's direct competitor, WRC 10. And there are some differences. WRC focuses more on the management part. You're not only a racing driver, you're also the manager of your own team. Winning and losing events directly influence you and your team. It's a lot harder to maintain a well balanced bank account, and the team might quit working altogether. 
Dirt Rally 2.0 is more friendly, as it leaves the management completely behind. It directly puts you behind the wheel, if you win or lose, there's no consequence. Upgrading/buying new cars goes a lot faster. 

Another difference would be the track design. WRC's tracks don't look as good as in Dirt Rally, but they're much more fun to drive through. They have more scenery, more unique buildings. The textures aren't as good, but it doesn't really matter when you drive past them in a 150km/h race car. 

The physics in both games can be a bit weird though. In Dirt Rally, you often have too little grip, while in WRC you often have too much grip. In both cases, hitting a small bush can rip off the entire bumper and shatter your headlights. In both cases, caution is still advised in tight corners and pitch black darkness.

Dirt Rally also put more focus on the FIA rallycross events. They're great fun to do, fairly competitive, even against ai. 

Another thing Dirt has is that it lets you complete daily/weekly/monthly challenges, in which you try your best to compete against other players. Not directly racing against them, but with the fastest times. The quicker you are in an event, the higher your reward. 

In the end, Dirt Rally is easier to get into. WRC is still a very good game though. However because of the reasons I've named, WRC isn't as new player friendly. You'll focus more on management than racing, and it can get confusing quickly. It's more styled for those that are into a full simulation of rally, while Dirt is more casual.

Great game, really. Its WAY better than the original Dirt Rally in many ways. But- the AI in RX is absolutely brain-dead. 

How can vegetables even get a license to drive, nonetheless RALLY. The AI off the start in RX (RallyCross) will do whatever is necessary to overtake you in the first 5 seconds of the race, even if that means pit-maneuvering you, or slamming into you forcing you off the track. It's miserable, and occurs regardless of AI difficulty. It looks like its intended to "make it more realistic/difficult" but frankly it does neither. It's just annoying.

In Open and Clubman, its very manageable. If you're half decent at driving, you can get a way better launch and be out ahead in 1st or 2nd with no worries. One you hit Pro is where the water gets murky. Basically every start, if you don't choose to be slower and take a lesser position, you WILL get spun out. I've tried multiple cars (sedan, hatchback) across multiple car manufacturers and it makes no difference. It essentially comes down to RNG and the track you're on, that determines whether or not the AI will spin you out if you're pulling ahead off launch.

I'll have a wonderful start: in Position 3, I overtake Pos. 1 off the start bc better car/launch- only to be spun out for no reason. Which quickly turns into a 6 car pileup on the track as every car on the line slams into me. Other times, ill be in Pos. 1 with a great launch and have no trouble at all- in the end, the AI is brain-dead and has no sense of sportsmanship to not play dirty. 

Aside from RX; standard Rally offers a variety of new locations, and some new VERY challenging ones- no complaints there. Not to mention new cars to pick from for Rally too! The Daily, Monthly, and AI challenges are also unique and interesting. Overall a great game, but the AI RUINS it for me. 

Edit: I feel like this review is a bit unfair to the game as a whole, overall I really like Rally 2.0; the physics experienced in rally and the cars being driven is very fluid and well done. Just steer clear of RX, the AI is infuriating.

Dirt has weird traction mechanics: for most of time the road feels like butter and not only for gravel surfaces but sometimes for asphalt. The lack of grip might be enjoyable for those who prefer drifting but it is far from what you would expect from your car in reality. (Well I would not expect my car to make 180 on flat surface just by turning left on 15 kmh). But yet it feels rather natural and even pleasurable on nordic maps with a heavy snowfall.
Other notices:
 + Xbox controller works fine
 + Graphics and effects are fairly good, so are maps
 + Big variety of vehicles (81 to be exact)
 + No need of Origin
 + It is possible to play short gaming sessions just by doing daily quests (each around for 10 mins)
 - DLC policy is cheeky
 - Risk of losing progress in singleplayer event due to internet connection
 - You can't press "recover your car" until you find a perfect spot where your car won't roll. And since the main game element based on finding an optimal balance between speed for staying on a track and speed for getting a nice time, it is quite irritaiting for the first 30 hours on maps with hills.

It feels like I'm actually driving a car when I plug in my wheel and play this game.

[b] NOTE: This review has been updated to reflect the time played. While I like the game, it still has issues people should be aware of. Buy only if the GOTY edition is at least 50% off. [/b]
[b]Before I get into any detailed info about the review, I'd like to put in some pros and cons of 2.0.[/b]
---
Pros:
Great graphics, nicely vibrant, everything blends in very well, resulting in pretty stunning environments sometimes.
Decently optimized, although older graphics cards and CPUs will stutter if you have the game set too high. My 1060 does the job.
Far bigger car variety than in the first game. Tuning is easier to understand. Physics feel better aside the occasional bruh moment.
New maps, some of which are still pretty great (New England for example). Maps themselves also have more varied twists, turns and terrain types.
Cons:
Rampant DLCs (if you didn't buy the GOTY edition, they WILL annoy you).
Always-online is a big con. If you're playing on the train like I do sometimes, then you're shit outta luck, as you need a stable connection to even do a career race. Speaking of which..Codemasters' servers aren't really up to par and sometimes you gotta reset five or six times to even get your race rewards.
Downright insane initial download - 110GB isn't exactly small for a game like this, even in 2022. For comparison, my Dirt Rally 1 download is **35GB**.
The game no longer receives any updates and you're probably risking losing the capability to play it entirely in a couple of years.
---
DiRT Rally 2.0 is a game I have always wanted to get, but I was always too poor for it and had a bad laptop, so I wouldn't run it anyway. That recently changed, and the second I put the game on my wishlist, the GOTY edition popped up on a 76% sale. Fifteen bucks? Sure, I'll have a spin.
2.0 is much more varied than the first title in some regards, but also takes a few steps back. The aforementioned DLC rampage is quite frankly annoying, and I wish Codemasters wouldn't try to wring out every penny from my bank account. The final update was recently announced, and it was 15GB to introduce one car, one nationality and a bugfix that didn't seem to fix any performance issues on my end.

Sometimes the servers shit the bed and you lose your rewards. Sometimes you can get them back. One time I lost a solid 1.2M credits thanks to the servers borking. Great stuff. I don't think Codemasters ever gave me those back.

So why the hell do I play it?

Cause it's fun?
Okay, I'll elaborate. But first, you should get something in your head, and that's two things:

1) Trying to get first place in DR2 is not that important. Enjoy yourself.
2) Fastest times aren't gonna help you if you destroy your car halfway through an event. [b] Consistency is key. [/b]

Yeah, the game will frustrate you sometimes. Not exactly a bad thing - rally races work like that IRL as well. When I was little, I kept watching WRC and I saw some pretty nasty crashes at times. This applies to 2.0 as well - one small mistake and you're flying off the track. Yeah, you can reset your position sometimes, but that mechanic is just as janky as in the first game. Sometimes the game still thinks you're moving a tiny bit and doesn't let you reset, and that takes up another five seconds, and even on max skills, the game sometimes decides you should get twelve seconds added to your split time. Not much that you can do about it.
Sometimes the physics also feel kinda weird - you can be scooting on a perfectly flat, smooth, asphalt road and suddenly, the physics disengage and you're flying off into the nearest tree. It happens. 
Some cars are also great for newer players (Opel Adam R2 and the Subarus), but some are just deathtraps that I wouldn't drive even with a drivewheel setup. Yeah, I use WASD and a PS5 controller. Sue me. Porsche cars are fucking deathtraps, and I'll never touch my Rally Spec 911 again. Hell, just don't touch Rally GT unless you're really good at tuning, cause those things are borderline undrivable stock. With Group B it's far less brutal somehow, even though those were historically actual murderwagons. Try tuning the BMW M1 if you can get it. It's fun. And the Peugeot Group B one.
---
Would I recommend 2.0? While Steam only has yes/no, my actual decision will be to [b]consider the game.[/b] If it's under 20 bucks, and that's the GOTY version, then sure, try it out. If it's the standard edition under 20 bucks, then don't bother. The same goes if both the versions are above $20. 
[b] Rally's hard, and so is this game. [/b] If someone calls this the Dark Souls of racing games, I will actually lynch them with their sack up first. Don't ever use that comparison ever again, and especially don't use it in front of me. This game is MEANT to be hard.

I want to love this game.

I've loved Dirt Rally 1, Dirt 2, Dirt 3, GRID (the original), GRID Autosport. I've loved game after game from Codemasters, but this is the only one I really despise. 
Not because the gameplay is bad, I love it. Every minute that I [i]played[/i] has been incredibly tense and fun. I love Rally, in general, and I would love this game.

But the always online DRM prevents me from playing the game. Each minute I have spent playing a race, I have spent "retrying" to connect to the bloody servers. On my record, at this moment, I have 6 hours. I have completed 5 tracks.
I loved those 5 tracks, and when the game is working, IF the game is working, it's amazing.
I'm not playing multiplayer, I don't really care to. I'm not starting an online league, or a racing club, because I don't want to. I'm trying to play singleplayer, pop on my favourite music and enjoy the game.

But that's rendered impossible when the race ends with a "connection to server failed" screen preventing me from starting the next race. My internet connection isn't down, my internet connection isn't interrupted, but whenever I try to play this game, it just doesn't bloody work.
I want to love this game, and one day, when Codemasters get off their ass and delete this ridiculous DRM for SINGEPLAYER, I will.

More of the same. If you liked the first DiRT Rally you cannot go wrong; bear in mind the first game has some areas that are superior to this game's.

The co-pilot's pace notes are a definite downgrade, and it's not the fault of the voice-actor who is fine. It's the notes themselves, and that's on the devs. Takes some getting used to and they're definitely not as properly tuned and timed as in the predecessor. Regardless of your timing settings you'll get some compression and decompression that will leave you flapping in the breeze, and there are some instances where too much info is given about flat-lefts while the looming sudden right turn is sprung on you late and with little emphasis. Also, I prefer "right three" to this game's inverse terminology of "three right." Seriously.

Another step backwards is that they removed the ability to change cars between events during career championships. This removes variety and options and forces monotony into the mix. Why the hell would a game developer want to force such a restriction?

Physics feel nice, maps are nice, etc and so forth.

By the way -- does any of the core player base REALLY like the rally-cross aspect of these games? Who among us wouldn't prefer more actual rally and/or hill-climb content (the hill-climb content which was tossed aside in  2.0) in place of the rally-cross content? 

I'd eagerly trade all the buzz-kill rally-cross content for a Mt. Washington hill-climb section.

I bought Dirt Rally 2.0 along with another motor sports game, and in my opinion DR2.0 has a more serious and mature tone, which I appreciate. I'm not into street racing games all that much, and I'm old, and therefore I appreciate it when games are not too childish.

I like the feel of the game, the user interface is very neat and clean. The graphics and the physics are amazing, the cars are beautiful. It's a lot of fun to drive with the sequential manual transmission, even though I play this game with a controller. I love that the game features real life rally course locations which feel real, and they are real (other motor sports games give little thought to this and thus feature fake and made up suburban cities that feel like ghost towns and look awful artificial, like nobody lives there).

This game features an offline play mode which is a very nice feature that I appreciate a lot. Just recently I had to spend a few days without an Internet connection and as a result I learned about the offline play modes which let you create your own private championships, which was cool.

The only thing I would complain about are that some of the DLCs cause the loading screens to take longer and they often cause game crashes. For example, I bought the Monte Carlo Location DLC and the Porche 911 RGT Rally Spec and they both worked fine. But then I purchased the Skoda Rally Fabia (a DLC car) and suddenly every loading screen would take a much longer time to complete and the game crashed about three times in less than a few minutes. So I removed the last DLC that I had purchased and everything worked fine again.

Overall I really really like the game, it's a lot of fun to drive the historic rally cars, and I've been playing nonstop.

This has to be the best racing game out there!
I am a casual-ish sim racing game enjoyer. I play with a wheel, pedals, stick and a VR. From all of the sim racing games I have played so far (AC, ETS2, this one and probably some others), this one is the best one by a long shot. The intensity this game makes is incredible and makes you feel alive as well as enjoy that fun of racing. No other game keeps you on your toes as you fly through the snowy Swedish roads with you Porsche 911 RS at around 180 km/h or when you stop thinking and just flow in the tracks of Poland while shredding the gravel in your Citroen C4 WRC. The intensity, the complexity and the variety really makes this my favourite sim-racing game.
The graphics are fine in my opinion, the immersion makes up for them. As when it comes to handling - seems pretty real-ish(I have had pretty wide experience with different drive-trains on different surfaces), though you can never really tell unless you have driven the same cars and make your own conclusions from there.
This game will test you, it will make you mad, happy and sad while you struggle to tame the beast these cars are in the game. This game is not for weak sissies, that are looking for a flashy racing game with drifting and high speed races. This game is for true racing enjoyers that are looking for a challenge with high reward.

So with 100 hours in the game I guess it's time to edit this review. When I wrote it I was using a logitech g29 wheel and was very dissapointed with the ffb. The ffb effects in DR2.0 are very harsh and "square edged" and in combination with the g29 gear driven motors it did not feel good. I'm now using a dd wheel with software filtering options and have after much tweaking found a way to make the ffb feel better. 

As for the game itself I've realized we gotta be grateful that we have a rally sim that can scale from controllers on low end pc's (and the steam deck) up to full motion rigs with dd wheels and vr support. There is nothing else on the market that can compete.

At the current pricing the game is absolutely worth it, recommended!

Pros: CAR GO BIG FAST UNTIL IT FELL ALL OF THE WAY APART, BEST VR GAME EVER 10/10
cons: I've actually had to learn a bit about cars in order to fully enjoy this game. ... Neat, I guess?

This game (or dirt rally 1), in VR, with a full-rotation, force-feedback steering wheel, is the single-most immersive "holy shit I feel like I'm actually there right now" experience I have ever had from a videogame in my life.

It's the force feedback that does it. In other games? Firing a gun in VR feels like a toy, grabbed in-game objects have no weight... but a steering wheel? A steering wheel fights back. And in this game, you can feel the gravel beneath your wheels. It's a hell of a time.

[Years-Later Edit: Got a computer upgrade and, now that I can run VR at a solid frame-rate, I am suddenly a hundred times better at this game. And it is so much more fun. Car go fast beep beep, braking is optional when you tilt your car forward a bit in Tuning because all-wheel-drive go brrrrrr. How am I suddenly decent at this game, I still don't know shit about cars, 20.5 out of 10. Still my favorite racing game; I think the key for me is not having to memorize tracks, because the co-driver tells me what to do.]

If you like cars - new and old - this is one of the best games you can get. Even now in 2022 the models, sound, feel, immersion is absolutely incredible.
I like track sims too, but I think on a track usually the nuances of surface and handling are hard to convey through a game. This is one reason stage rally is so good for computer games. You can really see and feel a lot of what's going on in the various surface types, degradation and weather conditions.
Handling is incredibly well translated from reality to game according to me (I don't really drive real cars) and more importantly according to real life rally drivers!
Your input's have a lot of effect on the handling. From how weight transfer changes grip of the tires and to how throttle and break control allows you to go sideways with relative ease.
Going sideways in a car is more addictive than you might realise, and this is one of the finest ways to experience it without serious environmental impact.
You can enjoy fine control of legendary rally cars whether you are playing with a wheel and pedals or a controller. Some even play with a keyboard, though I find it hard to believe it can be half as much fun. I play with controller now but have also played the game with a wheel for a while which was a lot of fun!
The locations are plentiful, varied and quite challenging. I promise you will never get to a point where you can complete them all perfectly without any issues. There is always room for improvement, and all have their own feel and character to their handling that you can learn to master through hours and hours of practice.
And what keeps us playing this game for months and years you might wonder? It is the the way in which the game has implemented community curated rally events called "Clubs", and the living breathing discord community and live streams. Especially for me the Barrel Rollers community where rivals are also the best of friends and also like a family with generations of rally enthusiasts.
NB!: This is a game where you should definitely get all the DLC as there is a lot missing in the base game. Many locations and even classes of cars.

one of the most rewarding videogames when you get it right,

the graphics are downright beautiful, although are slowly becoming dated. it could perform a bit better for what it is, i could make small complaints here and there but ultimately it has enough polish and replayability to warrant a thumbie upies

I have always loved driving games from the early 90s Test Drive and Indycar to the phenomenal Papyrus NASCAR games around 2000. And of course the very first Colin McRae Rally which quite frankly blew me away. Until then I only know the terrible RAC Rally videogames and CMR was huge leap in quality. The modern iterations: aka DiRT series on the other hand didn't make quite the same impression. I'm jut not into this show driving style. 

By no means I am a skilled driver, although over the years it became a hobby of mine to go the different tracks and take courses to learn how to handle race cars. I have to admit some basic instincts with real life implications were developed by playing these games. So... based on my limited real life experience the physics of DiRT 2.0 is not as realistic as I would have hoped. My all time favorite the Richard Burns Rally, a nearly 20 year old game still blows this one completely out of the water. 

But that's OK, I could still have fun even if the handling or rather the response of the car is surprising sometime. Feels too light and unpredictable. I could still enjoy the hell out of the Rally Cross World Cup if the AI wasn't rubber banding and way too aggressive to be realistic. In some ways handling resembles the 2011 Milestone release WRC 2: FIA Rally World Championship. And you know what? With all of its flaws I had more fun playing that...

I could still enjoy the Carrier Mode if I could just restart my stage every time after making a mistake, but I can't, because there are only a handful of restarts available, after that you have to exit and reload the last save. That my friends is big, big game breaking issue. Why? Because I simply don't have time to sit through the long loading cut scenes. I don't have time to go through the shake downs and meticulous setup of the car. I just wanna drive and enjoy. Which means I am learning the stages as I go, no practice. But the game forces me to waste time. And that's where Codemasters have dropped the ball.

After about 6 hours of gameplay I think I gave it a fair shake. And it just doesn't seem to get any better. The beautiful graphics nowadays simple doesn't cut it. That's just putting lipstick on a pig.

6/10

For this review, I will be comparing Dirt Rally 2.0 to Richard Burns Rally (with the Rallysimfans mod installed.)

Dirt Rally 2.0 feels lackluster. The improvements from Dirt Rally are minimal and it is still missing many features that are seemingly standard in most other racing games. After playing RBR for quite a while, I struggle with the weird physics of Dirt Rally 2.0.


I'm going to state up-front that I recommend Richard Burns Rally to anyone who wants a realistic rally experience.


Dirt Rally 2.0:

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

Looks fantastic. Great lighting and high detail.

The tracks are great. Beautiful environments.

The pacenotes are great. Clear reading with realistic sound and pacing.

Setting up controls for a wheel wasn't very difficult. It recognized my wheel immediately as well.

[h1] Cons: [/h1]

Physics are severely lacking. This is one of the biggest flaws with the game. The asphalt physics are notoriously bad. The cars feel like they're driving on ice. It doesn't feel like the tires are there or doing much of anything, giving you limited feedback. Certain tricks are unrealistically forgiving in their timing and difficulty to pull off. This may be a more arcadey sim game, but it sure acts like it wants to be a hardcore sim.

No replay recording/replays in general are terrible. Limited control over replays, have to use an external recorder if you want to save it.

Bloated game. 100gb file size because all dlc is installed even when you haven't purchased it. Nobody needs their drive space taken up by files they can't even access. This also means it's possible to hack the game and get the stuff for free because it's already installed.

Limited selection of tracks. While the tracks that are available are well made, there aren't many to choose from. In games such as this, you WILL eventually grow tired of doing the same maps over and over again.





Now on to Richard Burns Rally with the Rallysimfans mod installed.

[h1] Cons: [/h1] 

The graphics haven't held up all that well. It's game from 2004, so comparing it to Dirt Rally isn't really fair. That said, it doesn't look that bad for its age.

No menu built-in navigation using a racing wheel. You can only use the keyboard for navigation. However, [b] JoyToKey, [/b] a free to use software, can fix this. You can bind all the necessary keyboard keys to the buttons on your wheel and navigate the menus just fine.

The unmodded base game can be a pain to deal with and doesn't have amazing physics.

The pacenotes aren't great. They can sound somewhat robotic, and are lacking some information, as when the game was being developed, they tried to make it easy for anyone to understand.

Some parts of the game feel clunky.

The car sounds aren't very good. Some of them are for the wrong vehicle, and the volume can be weird.



[h1] Pros: [/h1]

(All of these refer to the modded version of the game)



Thanks to being abandonware, this game is free.

Rallysimfans mod is easy to install. It does everything for you, including installing the base game and mods. The guide on the site is easy to follow. The mod gets frequent updates, and is always improving.

The best physics of any rally game. The dirt feels perfect, and the tarmac is better than any other rally game. It feels like it should. It's not absolutely perfect, but it's a huge step ahead of the other rally games you can get.

Many, many cars. There is a wide selection of cars to choose from. While some have better looking models than others, they all drive great.

Enormous quantity of tracks to play on. Rallysimfans adds new tracks frequently. There is a huge selection of tracks, with more being added often.

My racing wheel was recognized immediately by the game. I didn't need to do much tweaking with it,

The rally school is great for learning how to rally.


TL;DR

Get Richard Burns Rally via the Rallysimfans.hu mod. It is a much more realistic rally experience, and it makes up for its flaws tenfold with what it does well.

THE best sim rally experience on PC. (RBR takes a bit too much time to setup for my taste.) Whether you are hauling ass in a Ford Escort (my personal favorite rally car) or flying through the forests of Finland in a more modern rally machine, you will gain a massive appreciation for the guts and skill it takes to pilot a rally car through a stage. Guttural and realistic sound design immerse you into the game while you hang on for dear life. Ample amounts of content for both fans of single-player and multiplayer mean that most people will find their preferred mode of operation. 

The only gripe I can think of is that the physics engine becomes a bit subpar when flying around on tarmac but it isn't game-breaking considering the vast majority of the time, you'll be racing and sliding around on dirt or gravel.

With just about every memorable rally car in history as well as a wide berth of locations that span around the world, this is Codemasters' Magnum Opus. 

Pro Tip: Pick up the GOTY Edition

This simulator is nothing short of exhilarating. I am not exaggerating. I love it! I play using a Valve Index at 120hz and the feeling of flying blindly down a dusty track only knowing what's coming around the hill or corner because the guy next to me is reading it off of a piece of paper is just incredible. I got this on a sale and then upgraded it to GOTY because I loved it so much. I highly recommend you do the same if you don't know if you're going to like it or not. If you buy the GOTY afterwards you get all the DLC's just not another copy of the base game. Easy.

The graphics look great in VR and the sound quality is top notch which is important to me when spending time in VR. I want things to look and sound good because I find it to be more fun that way. The championships against AI are easy at first but the more you do the harder the AI gets. You'll go from winning events like I was to rarely winning any anymore. Why? Because the sim is quite difficult! But that's what makes it so fun. Between Assetto Corsa, Assetto Corsa Competizione, and this, this is by far my favorite just because of how much fun it is. I'll include some controller settings to make things a little easier.

There is a career championship mode or you can create your own custom champtionships. There's rally racing which is mostly rural rough terrain tracks with lots of curves and hills and there's rally cross with are tracks that have tarmac and gravel. There are a bunch of single player modes you can play I don't need to list them all you will be pleasantly surprised by the variety. But best of all are the daily, weekly, and monthly challenges. They offer a wide variety of events with various types of cars and maps. I like playing these because it takes the decision making out of the equation for me.

You get credits for fininshing events. You can use those credits to buy cars, upgrade your team, or repair the cars you bought and roughed up on the track. The sim comes with some free cars you don't need to pay to repair and you can use those to accumulate more credits to buy better cars with when you're just starting out.

Dirt Rally 2 is one of the must-play VR games in my opinion. Nothing comes close to the feeling of flying and drifting down those tracks knowing you're potentially one mistake away from flying off a cliff! But you know what I love most about it? 

It reminds me of the 2008 fiat ponzi financial crisis and the housing market crash. There were huge areas in Florida where housing projects ran out of investment capital. There were these ghost towns of roads with street signs and no houses where the roads would just end and vast seemingly endless fields would begin. Me and my friends would drive out there in my Toyota Camry and tear it up in the muddy grass similar to how you drive in this simulator. When I first played I felt like I had some experience in this area :) Placing #6 on the leaderboard recently confirms that.

My video review and gameplay: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830910493

A good controller settings guide: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1668535147

I find this game near impossible to play on controller... You'll spend a lot of time tweaking the sensitivity adjustments and/or developing a very soft touch to be able to drive on the edge.

I'm just getting started, but I'm having a blast with this game so far. I initially wasn't very interested in dirt racing, but I heard good things and picked it up. It sat in my library for a while, but what made me actually download it and give it a try was it seemed to be the only game that had good VR with realistic manual shifting with an H-shifter.

You'll notice there seems to be only two reasons that people do not recommend this game.
1. You have to be connected to the internet, even if you are only interested in the single player modes.
2. The game is over 100GB because all the DLC is actually included in the game, you just have to pay to access it.
While I agree that these are both pretty abysmal practices, they have very little to do with the actual gameplay itself. [i]Even people who don't recommend this game admit that it is really fun[/i]. I'm not going to tell you that you shouldn't play this game just because of these two things. If you're able to look past them, give it a shot!

The one thing I will mention is this game mentions it has online PVP, which is misleading. If you're expecting to race against your friends, that's not something you can do. You are competing against each other's times on leaderboards and daily/weekly/monthly challenges.

Overall, this game looks incredible, feels amazing, and is just fun to play. If you have VR, this is a staple racing game for it and I highly recommend it for that. It's really immersive. You're not going to find this level of quality in most VR games at this price.

While its an amazing game, after 450+ hours of playtime I've had my fair share of genuinely broken and obviously hacky physics...
The graphics are great (not amazing, lacks a few things), the handling is good, even on controller. wheel support is a bit lacking and VR sometimes is weird.

7/10: too dependent on online connection (see other people's reviews talking about connectivity), graphics are good but physics are janky and inconsistent. I would put them in sim-cade territory with RNG slapped on, rather than anything near a proper simulation; with crashing forces (car stopping/spinning) being inconsistent, especially with Scotland's bushes and fences in every location. steering on controller has a set delay that a wheel doesn't have.

Recommended for:
Casual players despite the difficulty compared to full-arcade racers. 
And for hardcore players who seek something enjoyable with enough content for 200+ hours (including DLC and active clubs)

EDIT: after playing RBR for a while, and coming back to DR2 for a club event. DR2's physics feel even worse;
-the cars turn incredibly slow, and setting up for the turn results in either a very grippy corner, or sliding all the way through due to physics inconsistencies
-collision bounciness' inconsistency is incredibly clear, a nonexistent bump flipped my car but driving into a tree with my side does very little sometimes.

DR2 feels allot like an arcade game now, with the car turning on a pivot, the over-exaggerated physics and overall weird and hand-holdy controls that feel like the car wants to steer everywhere on its own (made even worse with a controller, but makes complete sense on a wheel)

Searching for something that feels like an actual simulation? i'd recommend the RichardBurnsRally installation from rallysimfans.hu; which objectively holds way more content than DR2+DLC.

I have 5 hours on Steam and I've played this game for over 2 years on the PS4, so don't let the low playtime fool you 
The good:
1, The graphics looks good on PC. Running on high settings with a gtx 1660 super and manages to hold a steady 60 fps
2, Good competition on the leaderboards for the most part
3, Good car variety if you own the DLCs
4, Controllers are usable and viable and not a utter joke unlike other sim type games.
5, A good variety of rally locations. It may not be as plentiful as WRC, but it is serviceable.
6, Good competition in the leaderboards.
7, A good rage game if that's your thing. 
8, The game is usually on sale, which means this game is dirt cheap for the most part.
 The bad:
1,The career mode is terrible without any meaningful rewards upon completing the masters championship. I've done masters multiple time on the ps4, and it was not worth it except for the challenge.
2, Bad co-driver call-outs at high speeds. If you drive fast enough, Phil may miscall his pace notes, which may lead to an accident.
3, Misleading call-outs at certain corners in the stage.
4, The DLCs are mostly Dirt Rally 1 content rather than original content for the game.
5, Not enough content if you don't own the DLCs. You won't even get snow locations without the DLCs.
6, Inconsistent suspension reactions. No matter how you tune the suspensions and dampers, it will always feel like a throw of the dice when you land from a jump or hit a bump. Your car will either land perfectly or bounce off the road and into a direction you didn't want to go in.
7, No meaningful progression since everything is unlocked from the get go in free play with Career mode being the only mode with unlocks, which is made almost useless since everything is in free play. It is only useful if you like running community events.
8,Poor damage model. The only severe damage you'll ever encounter are punctures, radiator and engine overheat, and the terminal damage when you crash head on into something. Even hardcore damage is a joke.
9, No grid girls. Hey, rally events still have them in real life, Codies. 
10,Floaty handling in tarmac. It feels like Codies never learns from their past mistakes.
11, Rallycross AI cars have different handling and weight. They will always grip the ground as if they're a gt3 car and you cannot ram them off the road,but they can do it to you which will lead to you throwing your controller out of your window.
12. Some serious bugs remain unresolved to this day, such as the milky rain bug and infinite loading.

 Overall, this game is a mixed bag. I would recommend it if you're a fan of cheap rally games,but the negatives are more glaring than the positives. I'd suggest getting this on a sale. I'd give this game a 7/10. If there was a neutral recommendation on steam, I would've picked that instead of a thumbs down.

The last proper rally games I played were 20 years ago, and to my surprise, jumping into this felt very instinctive and natural - like meeting with an old friend. I would imagine newcomers may find the game difficult to pick up at first, but what I can tell you is that I've been playing this exclusively with a controller (not a wheel), and after just a few minutes, I was able to get in the groove enough to play at 81-90 difficulty rating with consistent 1st and 2nd places. The graphics are excellent, the co-driver seems to be on-point with calling out what's coming up (not to mention the VAs, like holy crap, what a roster), and the gameplay itself is... gosh, it's so enjoyable. I love this game top to bottom.

When I first sat down to play muck I was expecting a bad free to play meme game. And what I got, was a New, Unique, and frankly Breathtaking take on the survival genre. This game is incredibly nuanced, with an extraordinarily deep, Intelligent, yet still challenging story, that will play with your emotions at every turn.

What this game feels like, is as if you gave an expert team of developers an infinite budget, and no time constraints, and told them to make what they want. Further, the graphics that this game provides are some of the best looking, realistic graphics that I've ever seen come from a video game, and it manages to keep My PC cold while doing so.

This game has one of the most intense, and rich story's out there, good enough to rival the likes of RdR2, the entire persona series, the kingdom hearts games, and much more. And with doing all of this, the game is still able to make downright genius social commentary on many real world issues. but not so much that it hampers the story in any way.

To play this game for free, truly is a blessing, Anyone who is out for money knows they could make millions off of this tremendous piece of art. and while, maybe we cant pay for this modern Picasso we can support the creator in other ways

I dont recommend this game for beginners to sim racing.  It is far to hard to learn on.  Pick up Car City Driving to learn the manual transmission if you want to play with manual H box.  Otherwise start with a simcade game like Forza Horizon or Wreckfest.  If you just bought a sim racing setup and want this game i highly recommend it.  However, please spend some time on easier games to learn your wheel, pedals, and box.  If you dont this game will put you off because of the difficulty curve.  It is IMO the best racing sim their is though on cheaper racing sim builds.

its great

Love this game to death it holds up super well even in 2022. Everything from the sound design of the cars, damage physics, and graphics of the environment is second to none. Some might say it's arcady compared to other rally sims, but it certainly gives you a great rally "feeling" which even if you've got the most badass sim racing rig, I'd still argue that feeling offers more realism to the overall experience to those looking for it.

Be prepared that it's different from most racing games in the way that it's not designed for you to win 1st place every time. I think this is why you see so many people out there talking about how hard this game is. They expect 1st place wins like every other racing game where you can just hit restart over and over until you win.. you cannot have that expectation here. You will frustrate yourself rather quickly if you do. If you learn to be happy with your own progress and learning curve, [b]drive conservatively[/b] like it's your own car, learn to listen to the calls, and not slam into every tree and off of every cliff chasing 1st place, I promise you will find immense improvement in your skill and times, along with tons more fun playing Dirt Rally 2.0.

..On the other side of things, I'd never tell you not to listen to the rally legend himself. If in doubt, flat out ;) good luck!

A fantastic game with unparalleled dirt and snow physics, graphics are great, cars handle nicely, a mostly realistic experience. It's a very difficult game and you'll crash a lot but that's the nature of rally racing whether it be real life or virtual. Those moments where you have a perfect run give such a level of satisfaction that you'd need to play to understand. 

It also has rallycross which is probably much more fun with people since the AI is ridiculous. They will sacrifice their position in the race to ram you off the road. When you try to ram them, it's like their cars weigh much much more than whatever you're driving. There's a little bumping in IRL rallycross but it's not supposed to be as egregious as it is in this game, it's like playing Wreckfest sometimes.

Definitely recommend a wheel. I played on controller for a good while but it's only good at teaching rally racing concepts. Actually performing things like heel-toe braking, Scandinavian flicks, or driving almost any RWD car will be borderline impossible on controller.

TL:DR If you like rally - buy, if you like rally and have poor internet, or are just new to the genre as a whole, consider



Pros:

1. I think that the game's physics are amazing, I never really found myself being betrayed by the game's mechanics, the engine or even bugs, for that matter. After playing for 83 hours, I can't really recall myself seeing any bugs, the game runs very well almost at max settings on a gtx 1080 with antialiasing enabled.

2. There are a lot of really well detailed tracks and locations, as well as cars, all of them look really authentic. Almost every country feels distinctive, apart from maybe New Zealand and Australia, for obvious reasons. And the cars have high quality sound and detailed cockpits, which is pretty surprising considering how many cars are in here.

3. 'm also fond of the soundtrack, especially that menu music, always makes me excited to open up the game and to hear that chill tune. This isn't an important part of the game, since you can only hear music between the stages, and in the main menu, but still, it deserved a passing mention.

4. But what I like most is the racing wheel support. I think it has been implemented here about as good as a sim racing game can, really. I've played some other racing games, and I really haven't found myself enjoying driving as much as I have Dirt Rally 2.



Cons:

1. I consider the game's biggest hindrance being not able to play offline, as indicated by other reviews, which I don't really mind, but I get why people are upset about it, and thought I'd warn you as well about this major detail.

2. This game is lacking some features, like being able to save replays and photo mode, as well as the UI being confusing at times when creating a custom championship for example. The last one is subjective, but the first two are a shame, since the game actually looks really beautiful, and being able to screenshot yourself drifting through a corner, or saving your replay of that one race where you've aced all of the corners.

All in all, I can say that this is probably one of my favorite, if not favorite, racing game for now. And you should really consider buying it, while the sale lasts till June 6th.

[h1]tl;dr[/h1]
This game is absolutely gorgeous fun to drive. It looks great and there are a great range of cars and tracks. I still feel it is a bit too heavily focused towards the hardcore masochist gamers but some small changes make it more fun for more casual gamers like me. I think it is worth getting the Game of the Year Edition as there are significantly more cars and locations.

[h1]Standard Edition vs Game of the Year Edition vs original Dirty Rally[/h1]
I bought the Game of the Year Edition when I saw the massive wall of DLC and concluded the base game must be a hollowed out shell of a game. Looking at the details now this is not true. The base game has more content that the original Dirt Rally but I do think the Game of the Year Edition is the better option.

[h2]Locations[/h2]
[table]
[tr]
[th][/th]
[th]Standard[/th]
[th]GOTY[/th]
[th]Original[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Rally[/th]
[td]6[/td]
[td]13[/td]
[td]6[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Rallycross[/th]
[td]8[/td]
[td]13[/td]
[td]3[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Hillclimb[/th]
[td]0[/td]
[td]0[/td]
[td]1[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Free roam[/th]
[td]1[/td]
[td]1[/td]
[td]0[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

The standard game rally locations are all new. Most of extra ones in the GOTY Edition are revamped versions of the ones from the previous game. The standard game does not include any snow or ice rally locations. 2 of the rallycross locations from the previous game remain in the standard game and the other one is included in the GOTY Edition. The hillclimb mode is completely gone which is a shame. I‚Äôm not really sure what the point of the free roam location is. Given it is based round the DirtFish rally school I‚Äôd speculate it was intended to be a tutorial level but it never got finished. The extra locations in the GOTY Edition integrate into career, time trial, custom and FIA World Rallycross Championship modes. They integrate into the daily, weekly, monthly events but these are heavily weighted to the standard game locations. These locations do not appear in the historic rally mode.

[h2]Cars[/h2]
[table]
[tr]
[th][/th]
[th]Standard[/th]
[th]GOTY[/th]
[th]Original[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Rally[/th]
[td]41[/td]
[td]57[/td]
[td]32[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Rallycross[/th]
[td]12[/td]
[td]25[/td]
[td]10[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Hillclimb[/th]
[td]0[/td]
[td]0[/td]
[td]4[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

Most of the cars from the previous game are are still present. A few have been replaced with slightly different versions but a few have fallen by the wayside such as the Hyundai i20 and the Mini Countryman. With one exception, all of the extra cars included in the GOTY Edition are new classes of car not in the standard game at all. These are:
[list]
[*]Group B (RWD)
[*]F2 Kit Car
[*]Up to 2000cc (These are late 90s early 2000s cars)
[*]Group B (Rallycross)
[*]RX Supercars 2019
[/list]
The extra cars in the GOTY Edition integrate into career, time trial and custom modes. They integrate into the daily, weekly, monthly events but these are heavily weighted to the standard game cars. The extra cars do not appear in the historic rally or FIA World Rallycross Championship modes.

[h2]Other[/h2]
As well as the new locations and cars the GOTY Edition also includes a bunch of extra starting money. All of the extra cars and a handful of cars from the standard game are unlocked from the start. This is nice as it really cuts down the amount of tedious grinding you have to do to save up for new cars and gives a lot more variety in the early stages of the game. The GOTY Edition also comes with a series of challenges based round the career of Colin McRae. These are really nice as it adds variety,  these challenges are not just about winning, they include goals like finishing without taking damage or finishing above a certain position when starting with specific damage.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
I think the extra tracks and cars are well worth getting the GOTY Edition. The more difficult question is should you still buy the original Dirt Rally as well as this game? I‚Äôd lean towards yes, it is not as polished as this game as this but you can get many more hours of gameplay out of it. Also I can see that these games are not going to appeal everyone so if you can pick up the original game for cheap in a sale you can save yourself the money of buying this one if it turns out to not be your cup of tea.

[h1]Review[/h1] 
My comments here are through the lens of what I thought about the original Dirt Rally which was that the driving experience was fantastic but it pandered too much to the hard core gamers and lacked the glue to make it into a great game.

So let‚Äôs start with the good. I cannot overstate how much fun the driving is in this game. There are so many different classic cars that are noticeably different to drive. In this game the weather and tyre wear seem to have a more significant effect. The tracks are nice and varied. The game looks and sounds gorgeous. The achievements are a bit more varied than the previous game which makes it a bit more fun to collect them.

Career mode was the main focus of the previous game but in this game I barely touched it. It is still too difficult and focused on grinding to unlock the tuned up version of the cars. It is however improved from the previous game. The levelling up of your crew is a bit nicer. The daily, weekly and monthly events are now done with the same cars you use in career mode. This makes the grinding for career mode much less tedious as you can have multiple events on the go at the same time and switch between them. Because you are racing against other people in daily, weekly and monthly events it is a much more level playing field. If you do a relatively smooth run with a few mistakes you will finish in the top 20-25% of a daily challenge against other people but dead last against the AI. It is way more satisfying to finish in the top 100 on a challenge against other people that it is to hopelessly thrashed by the arbitrarily difficult AI. There are a lot more of these events than the previous game too.

I really like the addition of Historic rally and FIA World Rallycross Championship modes. For me these were where the most of the fun was to be had. You skip all the tedium of career mode and can just get behind the wheel of all your favourite cars but with a nice sense of progression as you unlock more events. I just wish this section of the game was bigger and featured more of the extra content of the GOTY Edition.

A few other minor quibbles. I didn‚Äôt like the new co-driver I found him too animated in his speech, I preferred the previous less emotional, consistent directions but I got used to it. Still no Toyotas, I realise this is probably due to some boring licencing agreements but in my head it is because someone in the team is still holding a grudge from the 1995 WRC. Being able to set the name that appears on the car is a nice touch but why not make this work with the realistic liveries as well? In a similar vein it would be nice if the cars had decals specific to the different rally locations. I still think it would be nice to have more of the assists from Dirt 3 like the time rewind to make this accessible to more casual gamers. It would also be nice to have a bit of AI in the spectators. It does break the immersion when you crash and the spectators just stand there indifferent to their inevitable demise. I realise getting them to all jump out the way like in Driver San Francisco is a bit of an ask but they could at least react to the car.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
So there are a few things I would have done differently if I was in charge of this game but overall this has to be one of my favourite racing games.
