But sometimes the ai just punt you off full speed, sometimes being unable to prevent it all together. But if you can look past the ai, the game is great.
Dont have many hours yet, would definitely recommend, excellent game, feels realistic. Something worth noting is that the game is not a walk in the park, it takes a bit to get good at

This game is a total disappointment, I don't know where in history gaming stopped being fun and became a source of frustration and stress. Is very unfortunate, because is way superior to Dirt 4, but the AI is just unbeatable, even with the easiest settings (and you don't have much control over settings). Total trash for casual players and having fun (the ultimate goal of gaming). Avoid this games unless you are masochist or professional rally player or you want to waste a lot of time repeating the same race over and over (going fast as hell and making no single mistake) again until by pure chance you win.

The game is cool, well developed. BUT! Of course, it's good to go through long tracks dozens and dozens of times, and yet it starts to bother. Maybe the problem is in the player, but I can‚Äôt put up with the fact that the game really quickly gets bored.
There are no particularly nasty, noticeable, big problems with the game, but the main problem is that the game really quickly gets bored. In general, for me the game is like in the rally genre, racing has gone very well, and you can safely call this game the one you will return to sooner or later. Therefore I put a class.

car.

One of the worst rally games ever made because you cannot completely fix damage to vehicles - while it is very realistic with a realistic damage model once a series of races is complete it is not always possible to replace damaged parts, which is why I stopped playing the game after 19 hours.  I could no longer win races with a damaged car because I could not replace parts to get the car back to 100%.  While I understand there is a time limit to fix the car between stages so you can only fix what you have time for is a part of real life rallying, not being able to get the car back to 100% after an event is finished is not.  This is the only issue that I had with the game, other than that, the graphics, sound, physics and realism are excellent and it would have been an excellent game if damaged parts could have been replaced when a car was not competing in an event.  I bought the game soon after it was released and stopped playing it a week later because I couldn't fix my car.  I played the game over a year later and while I had more options to replace some of the parts, I still could not get the car back to 100% and was extremely disappointed and never entered another race and deleted the game.  If Codemasters think that gamers would prefer to race damaged cars that cannot win races because in some fucked up pipe dream of theirs they feel that it adds to the realism, then as far as I am concerned they can take their server hardware and take turns shoving it up their asses while they all smoke crack.  The fact is that race teams will replace anything and if necessary everything on a car to get it back to 100% when the car is not racing in an event and that's a cold hard FACT.  If Codemasters want to make a 100% realistic rally game, then they should allow players to fix their cars properly, just like race teams do in real life.  This fatal flaw made the game unplayable for me after about 17-18 hours and I will never buy another Codemasters game ever again because they could have very easily fixed this very obvious flaw, but chose not to.  Fuck you Codemasters.

However, in this world of constant algorithmic attention grabbing, nothing provides me more of a brain break than Dirt Rally 2.0. The moment your brain starts to lose focus, you're in a ditch, or wrapped around a tree. This game is all about focus and flow state.

Bought it on sale for 5EUR. Playing it with max settings at 1440p (40-45fps) on i7 10700, AMD 5500XT 8GB DDR4 32GB 2666MHz runs excellent. One of the most beautiful graphics seen ever, wonderful optimistic music (intro&outro screens) easier and way more fun then Project Cars. Starting screen is little bit confusing, need time to figure out how to start the game in first place. I just wanna start driving and enjoy the scenery while listening to the sports anchor voice of the co-driver "four on the left, next jump...". But once figured it out, it gives a lot of driving pleasure. It lacks also hints about what car is best for certain terrain.
It would be nice if the DLC was included for free, yet on discount is really cheap only 1.5-2EUR.
Winter snowy roads of Sweden and Monte Carlo are my favorite DLC's.

There's something about Dirt Rally 2 that makes me want to play the game for countless hours. Is it because of the dynamic rally stages? the overwhelming graphics? the realistic engine sounds? is it because of the Subaru Impreza? the heavy feeling of the Lancia Delta's handling? the satisfying force feedback on your racing sim? or is it because you love Colin Mcrae?

Nevertheless, the game is truly one of a kind. DR2 slashes on their competitor/s with their amazing mechanics and outstanding display of rally racing gameplay. The number of historic and memorable cars in DR2 still overshadows their lack of official WRC cars making it look like your everyday rally racing in your local area.

I am so torn about this game, having recently got back into it I both love it and want to strangle it if that was possible.  As a driving game you can just drop into to have fun this and the original Dirt Rally are my favourite driving games.  I don't pretend to be any good though.  

Yesterday I came 6th in Germany the first time I've got points in 2.0.  Dirt Rally lots of times or even most of the time but not as easy in 2.0 as yet.  However this morning the games server failed and when I went back to my career it wiped my career out totally.  So however good the game is I can't recommend it because it relies too much on the internet and screws up.   I did nothing wrong and I have good fibre internet.  The original Dirt Rally used the internet as well but in what must be hundreds of hours I never had a problem once.  To have a fun impressive game ruined by over relying on the internet is really bad and ruins the game.

Punishingly difficult, but fun. Rallying is a very visceral sport and this game succeeds at conveying that.

Prepare to go into the trees more times than you can count but the joy of nailing a section or a stage is incredible. 

Sound design is top-notch and graphics are good as well. This is where Codemasters uses their expertise in creating casual simcades like the F1 games and the regular DiRT series comes into place where eye and ear candy take precedence over physical accuracy. And it is where a lot of the simulators falter. This game also has great creature comforts like automatically detecting my (very common) Logitech G29 and I can go through all the menus using the wheel (unlike for example Assetto Corsa which still expects you to use your KB/M).

Multiple ways you can enjoy this game, either play solo against bots, play the daily/weekly/monthly challenges or join a club where you race championships together.

The fact that every little thing requires a connection to the server is ridiculous. I'm writing this as the server is down. 

Your career money?
$0 unless you're connected. 
Just finished a time trial race?
Be prepared to wait for 3 minutes for it to "Connect to server" if the server is down.
Wanna restart a race?
Same. Wait for 3 minutes if server is down.
Start the game?
Same. 3 minutes if down.
Starting a race?
Same. 
Going back to main menu?
You guessed it.

What kinda bullshit? How dumb is this implementation? Won't recommend this dumb game. You're better off Arr-ing this game if you can't even play it when their own servers are down.
